This game is so great I can feel my cells dying

This game saved my life.

I am 49.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

As someone who does not enjoy the game design of roguelikes in general, I couldn't put this game down.  The combat is fluid, there's enough variety in routes to keep things fresh between runs, and the art and soundtrack are both amazing.   And it's addictive as hell.  Worth every penny at full price.  

It's clear the devs put a ton of effort into this game.  It's polished, and has plenty of DLC content to enjoy as well.  If you are into roguelikes, this is a must play.  If you're not, or even if you downright dislike the genre like me, it's still a must play.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

In the depths of the Amazon rainforest, amidst the vibrant tapestry of life, resides a creature of extraordinary beauty and enigmatic nature: the emerald tree boa.

Its sleek, iridescent scales shimmer like a thousand tiny emeralds, casting an ethereal glow upon its surroundings. Its body, reaching lengths of up to 10 feet, is adorned with intricate patterns that resemble ancient hieroglyphs. The boa's head is triangular, with piercing golden eyes that seem to penetrate the very soul.

Beneath its scales, the emerald tree boa possesses a remarkable adaptation: heat-sensing pits located between its eyes and nostrils. These pits allow it to detect the body heat of its prey, even in the darkest of nights. With lightning-fast reflexes, it strikes with deadly precision, its sharp fangs sinking deep into its victim's flesh.

Curiously, the emerald tree boa is known to have a peculiar dietary preference: it exclusively feeds on birds. Its arboreal lifestyle allows it to ambush its feathered prey from the safety of the treetops. Using its prehensile tail, it coils around branches, patiently waiting for an unsuspecting bird to come within striking distance.

Another fascinating fact about the emerald tree boa is its ability to change color. When threatened, its scales darken, blending seamlessly with the surrounding foliage. This remarkable camouflage technique allows it to evade predators and remain undetected in its rainforest habitat.

In the realm of reproduction, the emerald tree boa exhibits a unique courtship ritual. Males engage in elaborate displays, swaying their bodies and flicking their tongues in an attempt to attract a mate. Once a pair has bonded, they perform a synchronized dance, their bodies entwined in a graceful embrace.

As the sun sets, casting long shadows across the rainforest, the emerald tree boa emerges from its daytime slumber. Its eyes gleam with an otherworldly intensity, and its movements become fluid and graceful. It is a creature of mystery and wonder, a testament to the boundless diversity of life on Earth.

Playing Dead Cells felt like an exercise in futility at times, almost as if my friends enjoyed watching me fail repeatedly more than anything else. Although I recognize that the cycle of dying and retrying is a core part of its gameplay loop, it lacked sufficient appeal to keep me engaged. There wasn't enough variety or progression to motivate me to continue facing the same punishing challenges over and over. The game certainly has its merits and a dedicated fan base that appreciates its difficulty and mechanics, but for me, the incentive to push through the repetitive cycle of defeat wasn't strong enough to maintain my interest.

dead cells is an absolutely fantastic game! it's a must-play for anyone who loves challenging, fast-paced action. the pixel art style is simply stunning, and the soundtrack is so catchy it'll have you tapping your foot while you slice and dice your way through enemies. the gameplay is smooth as butter, and the roguelike elements keep you coming back for more. it's addictive in the best way possible, and with each run, you'll discover new weapons, abilities, and upgrades that will make you feel like an unstoppable force. the difficulty level is just right - challenging enough to keep you on your toes, but not so punishing that it becomes frustrating. trust me, once you start playing dead cells, you won't be able to put it down. it's a modern classic that deserves all the hype it gets

Dead Cells is one of the fastest and most slick roguelites out there. One of the best ways to make sure players come back to playing a game like this where action and speed are the focus is just to make the movement feel snappy and fun- I'll admit it took me a long time to get a good handle of the platforming in this game, but when I did eventually get the hang of it, it eventually became just SMOOTH, man.

The game is hard and punishing but rarely in a way that feels arbitrary, just occasionally cruel in a tongue-in-cheek way. I've still never cleared through BC4 and I don't know that I ever will see the true ending of Dead Cells, even now that it has been forced to stop development (by the by, Motion Twin, a curse upon your families <3 dont do stuff like that and maybe you'll have a real reputation in the future, if this boneheaded decision didn't damage it already beyond repair. won't be buying windwhatever though) 

The amount of content packed into the whole extent of Dead Cells with its DLCs cannot be easily overstated; if you like the format I guarantee you won't exhaust the game's environments, weapons and interesting secrets for many dozens of hours at least. It lived in my head enough for me to invest 250+ hours and I've barely even explored some of this game (Castlevania DLC has kicked my butt!) so you will likely be able to immerse in it for just as long

This game is unfortunately just too grindy for how boring the gameplay loop is. The awkwardly-laid-out procedurally-generated levels get old fast, there are not many enemy types, and you're stuck with the base weapons for far too long 1) because of how expensive the upgrades are, and 2) because of how many essential upgrades there are before it makes sense to unlock many weapons. The bosses I've encountered so far are all joyless damage sponges that take forever to whittle down. They're tedious to the point that I have zero interest in fighting them again, but you need to do so hundreds and hundreds of time if you want to grind for more than a sliver of what this game has to offer (and there are even multiple boss rush style minigames if fighting the same bosses hundreds of times in the core game wasn't tedious enough). Even the soundtrack, which was fine enough at the start, has so many variations on the same theme over the different levels that I'm quite sick of it.

Another major frustration is that there's often so much going on on the screen that it's tough to see what you're hitting and what's hitting you. This made me gravitate to bows that would let me kill enemies from off screen with limited risk (boring) and strong melee weapons that would stun the enemies I was hitting so I could button mash and not worry about taking damage from an attack I couldn't see (mindless). Almost none of the weapons I've used so far felt smooth and satisfying to use, as even the fast swords take a fraction of a second to swing and the arrows take a fraction of a second to nock. Everything just feels slow, and as far as I can tell you're animation locked and can't roll cancel your attacks, which leads to a lot of cheap damage.

With that said, it's commendable that this game runs at 1080p / 60 FPS and without noticeable input lag on a dual-core Celeron from 2015 with integrated graphics. Even in 2D games I often have to reduce resolution to get a consistent 60 FPS, so I was impressed by the smoothness here.

I also appreciate the number of very nice gameplay settings that allow you to do things like jump just as long as you have the jump button suppressed, hold the attack button to continue your combo, and hide lore rooms. Unfortunately all of these options are all off by default and I discovered them after I decided I was done with this game... They wouldn't have been enough to redeem my other issues, but if I had been aware of this earlier and/or if some of the key ones had been on by default, I would have had a better experience. If you ignore my review and decide to play this game anyway, at least be sure to give the settings a good look.

If you're looking for a roguelite, Hades is the gold standard; play that instead. The story and progression system were far more effective at keeping the grind fun. If you're looking for a 2D side-scroller with good combat, try basically any metroidvania (e.g. Blasphemous). I've had nothing but better experiences in that genre.

I'm playing this game with limited DLC content, but even without all the fantastic DLC I'm having a great time with this smooth roguelike. It takes a bit of time to get into the progression of this game, and it wasn't until about 20 hours in that I had my first win. After that it's been smooth sailing, the progression and difficulty options open up and it's a lot of fun. 

There's definitely a few weapons that I prefer so far, but I'm happy to say I have many more weapons to unlock and paths to take. I recommend this game for all action roguelite platformer fans (but not for metroidvania fans, it doesn't quite scratch that itch)

Imagine the game as a 2D roguelite with heavy focus on combat but where similar games hardly offer any real exploration here it gets a metoidvania vibe. don't be mistaken, in the end this game is a linear 2D action game, but every run feels varied enough and especially paired with the fantastic DLCs (which I also would highly recommend) the whole level structure resembles a Starfox style level progression.

Also the music, graphic design and the tidbits of lore here and there are well done and keep you well engaged. Don't underestimate the difficulty though. My first complete run took me about 30 - 35 hours to achieve with the run itself taking about 45-60 minutes.

Honestly if you can even remotely think of that as a fun experience you should give it a try.

Dead Cells : By Triple F

Steam's vast library of games has seen its fair share of rogue-likes, but among the myriad choices, there stands an undisputed champion – "Dead Cells". Developed by Motion Twin, this game transcends the boundaries of its genre, delivering an adrenaline-soaked experience that leaves players utterly captivated from their first electrifying encounter to the heart-pounding final showdown.

"Dead Cells" is a visual spectacle that seamlessly blends pixel art aesthetics with modern design sensibilities. The meticulously crafted environments pulse with life, showcasing a diverse range of atmospheric settings that unfold in a symphony of colors. The game's attention to detail is nothing short of awe-inspiring – from the subtle play of light in dimly lit caverns to the frenetic explosions of vibrant energy during heated battles. Each frame is a work of art that engulfs players in a world as dangerous as it is mesmerizing.

The game's combat is a symphony of fluidity and precision. Every slash of your weapon, every dodge roll, and every well-timed parry carries a palpable weight that reinforces the player's connection to the protagonist. "Dead Cells" deftly combines strategic decision-making with lightning-fast reflexes, creating an intoxicating game-play loop that never grows stale. The intuitive controls become an extension of the player's will, allowing for endless creative approaches to each skirmish.

What sets "Dead Cells" apart from its contemporaries is its ingenious take on the rogue-like formula. Death is not an end, but a new beginning. The constantly shifting levels and enemy placements ensure that each foray into the unknown is a unique challenge. The game offers a wealth of weaponry and abilities that can be tailored to suit your preferred play-style, encouraging experimentation and evolution as you uncover devastating synergies. This creates an irresistible loop of progression and discovery, urging players to push their limits and delve deeper into the labyrinthine world.

The haunting melodies and atmospheric soundscapes of "Dead Cells" are an auditory delight. From the haunting echoes of desolate corridors to the pulse-pounding rhythms of intense battles, the music becomes an essential companion on this treacherous journey. It not only complements the visual splendor but also elevates the emotional resonance of each moment.

"Dead Cells" presents its narrative with an intriguing subtlety that beckons players to piece together the story as they progress. The game leaves breadcrumbs of lore and tantalizing hints about the world's mysteries, encouraging a deeper engagement without imposing a rigid narrative structure. This enigmatic approach creates a sense of wonder and curiosity, making the discovery of hidden secrets all the more rewarding.

Ultimately, in the grand tapestry of video games, "Dead Cells" shines as a masterpiece that defies conventions. Its breathtaking visuals, exhilarating combat, and ingenious rogue-like design coalesce into an experience that is as addictive as it is unforgettable. With each run, you'll uncover a new layer of its brilliance, ensuring that "Dead Cells" remains an essential fixture in any gaming collection. Motion Twin has not just created a game; they have forged an enduring legend that will resonate for years to come.

Dead Cells understood the assignment. For those in there mid-30's and beyond, remember back to the days of original Nintendo. Dead Cells doesn't give the real original Nintendo feel, it gives you the trumped up version of the original Nintendo games when you were younger. Not quite 8 bit, but rather in an 8-bit style, with better lighting, better sound, and significantly more color depth. It is literally everything you want without any of the drawbacks that actually existed when you were younger.

I paid 17.99$ for the game and all DLC and it was worth it in spades.

The user interface or rather "Controls" are beautiful. What gives this game the perfect nastalgic feel is adding music with fidelity and graphical layering that wasn't possible with Nintendo. The feel of your first love, but as good as you remember, not the poor quality it actually was. Music, graphics, color contrast, story, controls, weapons... every aspect is polished. Well worth the money. I can't say it's a 40$ game with DLC and all. But for 20-25$ when on sale, it's worth it all day long.

P.S. if you aren't into the graphics, don't play the game. This is a blast from the past, but everything is better kinda game. Not for everyone, but 5-Star all day long for the audience it was meant for.

It's... fine I guess, I’d consider it overrated for its overwhelmingly positive reviews on steam when it’s a ~6/10 game – with passable and functional gameplay, without being innovative or exceptional in its genre.

[h1]Gameplay/Combat[/h1]
Hit stuff with melee/ranged weapons until they die, with occasional dodge rolls/shield parries; or simply run past enemies to get to the next level and reach the next boss; rinse and repeat until the final boss – hopefully you’ve collected enough attribute scrolls & good enough weapons to reduce the boss’s hp to 0 before yours run out.

Having finished to the end in about 6 hours, the replayability of the game seems a bit concerning considering subsequent runs becomes stale rather quickly. The meta progression aspect of the roguelite contributes a bit to its staleness I think, because it takes a bit too long to unlock new weapons/traits/tools etc, thus you play with the same repetitive tools for quite a bit until you accumulate enough cells unlock the next one.

Not a big fan of the stat system, which incentivizes upgrading a single attribute as high as possible, it restricts your equipment pickup options only to those sharing the same color, as the ones aligned to other attributes will be significantly weaker.

Upon completion of levels there are reward doors which you may be able to open if you finish the level quick enough, or kill enough enemies/kill the boss without taking damage, which I think functions well to reward skillful plays, but also impacts exploration negatively

[h1]Exploration[/h1]
Exploration isn’t intuitive, an external guide and a lot of mental notes is required if you want to get to a specific level, unless you’re into stumbling around blindly In a maze, while a timer runs down potentially locking you out of additional rewards. For instance, to get to the Slumbering Sanctuary to obtain the spider rune, you need to pass through Prisoners’ Quarters => Toxic Sewers (vine rune) => Ancient Sewers(ram rune) => Insufferable Crypt => Slumbering Sanctuary, which you’d probably need to learn from an external guide because the game doesn’t do a good job incentivizing exploration by providing information in-game that leads players to actually take different paths instead of the same one over and over. The world map UI does a poor job in explaining which biomes connect to which, which requires which traversal tool, and which is currently inaccessible; also doing a shit job at incentivizing exploration.

The level completion timer locking off rewards disincentivizes thorough level exploration. Granted, Dead Cells uses semi-randomly generated 2d levels, in which 100% exploration of a level isn’t particularly helpful because it will change on the next visit. However, the element of which biomes are connected to which and which traversal tools is required to reach which remains the same throughout the runs. Repetitively getting into dead ends in Dead Cells because you don’t have traversal tools unlocked or DLCs unlocked or that simply because it’s a dead end feels timewasting and potentially punishes you by taking away resources simply because you travelled the wrong random direction by chance, and that door at between levels will remind you of that.

DLC levels sucks two-fold: cluttering up the world map UI with inaccessible areas, and acting like more dead-ends in game, some of which has long corridors before you’re told you can’t access it. Having DLC elements not appearing in game unless you’ve purchased it would improve the game for base-game players; but I suspect the developers would rather try to manipulate people who already bought their game through FOMO.

[h1]Writing[/h1]
Not particularly good, but the roguelike/lite genre isn’t known for good writing in the first place (probably with Hades as an exception), more often than not relying on addictive repetitive gameplay loops – and replayability is already an issue with this game.

I would say though that placing a shit-ton of easter eggs doesn’t really make the game “cooler”, it just dilutes the game’s identity (currently about half of my weapon unlocks are easter egg weapons) and make its world less believable.

I was really enjoying this game. I played for almost 65 hours with no issue. Then one day, I got an error and it crashed my game. I figured it was no problem, I'll just reinstall it, verify integrity of files, and it will work. Didn't work. Decided to try my laptop with the game, didn't work. So I had no choice but to ask for help. I pinged motion twin on twitter for help. Nothing. I sent an email to their support. Nothing. I made a reddit post asking for help. No one replied. So at this point, after investing so much time into this game, I just have to quit because their dev team just doesn't care to fix or help the game in any way or help the players. whole experience has soured my opinion of this developer. I supported them by purchasing all the dlc because I enjoyed this game. I feel conned, and I urge people who are considering this game to realize that these devs will take your money, but vanish when there is an issue. Despicable.

I absolutely understand the allure of Dead Cells and it deserves tons of credit for it’s innovation. However, I’m just not a big fan of having to restart from the very beginning in a game and having weapon drops be random. There was a part of me who wanted to try collecting as much as I could and eventually DL the DLC but I just do not see the point. If you like the added challenge of having to restart from the beginning and using different tools to advance this is certainly for you. But it gets very dull having to redo the first few levels again and again.

I would much rather play something like Hollow Knight which increases difficulty in all sections as time moves forward with randomly spread-out bosses there is no general order to fight. I have never played Dark Souls before but many have said it shares similarities to it due to frequent deaths and restarts.

In any case definitely not a bad game and worth beating at least once but I don’t have much desire to go further.

Dead Cells is one of the friendliest rogue-lites I've played, the meta progress is really quick at the start, there are almost no bad weapons and exploration is rewarding. The endgame stalled for me though, once you have explored all (most of?) the biomes, the builds you like... now you just want to beat the game but it takes a slip to end a great run and you start doing worse each try as now you are rushing things and missing on power ups.

Now my problem with rogue-lites is that they make you gamble with your precious free time and Dead Cells is no exception. I was starting to getting annoyed with sinking 20-30 minutes a run... but if you feel the same as I do you should go into the game's AWESOME accessibility mode settings and give yourself a few extra lives, or just reveal the map for guaranteed power ups.

I recently played the demo for some other game and it was OK but it really just made me want to play Dead Cells again. Man. This game. I think I originally played DC on the VIta, PS4, then again on Switch, and now on PC/Deck. It's like Skyrim in that way that I will probably always have a copy of it on every console I ever own. It feels timeless and holds up just as well in 2024 as it did back in 2018. 

And now I got all the DLC that's come out and it's just sort of dawning on me how much I love this game. Like, top 5 of all time love this game. It's so hard to explain exactly why. 

I never paid attention to the story except that your MC is a total smarta**, a blob of goo inhabiting shells of humanoids to complete runs, collecting dead cells to roguelite it up, and that's about it. That's probably all you need to know. 

What really matters in Dead Cells is the gameplay. That sweet sweet trance state of gameplay that Dead Cells induces in me like no other game has been able to do. It feels like my brain is drooling on itself when I play. 

First off, Motion Twin, thank you. For everything. And thank you to the numerous other indie devs who have participated with Motion Twin in making some of the most fun and hilarious cross-over content I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing. 

Beyond that, there is something with Dead Cells that occurs at this particular intersection of play where you 1. have cultivated a heavenly loadout, 2. are familiar enough with your surroundings to feel competent (but you will be punished SEVERELY for any lapse of attention, no matter how brief), and 3. you are in a movement flow with both your MC and the BGM that makes you feel like an unstoppable wave of pain, and it's this intersection that I am trying to find in each run and it's NEVER a disappointment. 

In roguelite fashioin there are so many upgrades, mutations, and configurations that even items you don't care for (*cough*NUTCRACKER*cough*) can have a benefit or use. And I won't get into all of that because there is just SO much of it now. Each run is almost never ended in vain. 

I am still working through the new content and new items but so far I have found that if I just lean into something I have a good time. Some loadouts I thought were going to be total crap ended up being a total blast and got me a lot farther than I expected. There is a fluidity of movement that the MC has that is almost idescribable. Sometimes this is dependent on your loadout and playstyle - I tend to play very aggressively and I feel rewarded for it. Everything has an appropriate sense of weight and impact, and I always feel confident about where the MC is at in space even when things get hectic on screen. Quickly running through and wiping out a map while using both weapon slots and both accessory slots (and backpack) produces such a delightful rush of endorphins. 

I also really love the ENTIRE art direction and OST/BGM. Really no complaints from me at all on those areas. I love the enemy design and variety, even the real PITAs, I have enjoyed the boss encounters, and I have also, surprisingly, enjoyed every biome so far, even ones I don't traditionally enjoy like Sewers. 

HLTB says 30 hours for main + extra, 90 hours for completionist, not including DLC which can add another 30-ish hours (up to and including Return to Castlevania). I think this is all going to be dependent on your enjoyment and skill with Dead Cells. 

I have had zero technical issues with the game, both on PC and Deck (and every other console for that matter). 

It's just pure video game FUN. If you like action platforming/2D action, roguelites, your a** is getting burned by all the sOuLsLiKe MeTrOiVdVaNiAs, or you just want to see what the fuss is all about I urge you to pick this up over any other.

It's not the worst game in the world by any means, but this is 6/10 game for me, and it's hard to recommend when I had such an incredibly frustrating time beating it. 

This game is designed for masochists, it's extremely unforgiving in a bad way. The game likes to reward you for not getting hit in a biome (Levels), or bosses, that you are guaranteed to fail constantly after stage 1, or maybe stage 2. The enemies and bosses can be seem unpredictable, and seem to hit you when it looks like they are in hit stun. 

 If you like getting 100%, this game is also cryptic in the most asinine ways, be prepared to constantly look up guides to get through it.

If you want a good rogue-like, I'd recommend either 20 minutes till Dawn, or Hades instead. Both are way better designed overall.

If your looking for a metroid-vania rogue like game, you've come to the right place.

I hate rogue-likes.  I generally hate rogue-lites, too.

I like Dead Cells.

I actually have trouble putting it down.  Now, in fairness, I also like Super Metroid, some of the Castlevanias, Hollow Knight, probably a couple others, so 2D platforming with upgrades is clearly something I'm in to.

The things that turn me off for rogue-lites is that I always feel like I'm losing too much every time I die.  I feel like there's no progress.  The game is usually far too hard, and I feel like I'm just running on a treadmill.

There are a lot of variables a game developer can play with when making a rogue-lite.  I think Dead Cells got the balance here just right:
[list]
[*]The game is fast.  You move pretty fast.  You're spending most of your time playing the game and very little time in cutscenes (often skippable) or loading screens.  When you die, you're back to a new run in maybe twenty seconds.
[*]I've probably done thirty runs so far, and I'm still seeing a variety of content.  I feel like I might see something new every run.  I imagine that might change after hundreds of runs, but right now I feel like I'm rewarded every run I make.
[*]Likewise, every run I feel like I'm making it a [i]little[/i] bit further.  My power-ups are making me a [i]little[/i] more powerful.  If the difficulty was one hair higher, my desire to play this game might be much, much less.  (There is an "assist" mode you can turn on that probably makes the game easier.  I haven't tried that yet.)
[/list]

So: Tons of content (I have all DLC), tight loop between runs, difficulty is just barely low enough for me.

The only other thing that I think probably makes this game more playable for me is that I'm playing it on my Steam Deck.  Since you're not able to save, when I have to go to "adult things" that can't wait, I can just put the Deck to sleep and pick it up again later.  If you don't have that sort of freedom with your computer, this may be a problem.  However, I do feel like they should just let people save in the middle of a run.

Finally, the controls are really, really good.  All the movement feels absolutely [i]fluid[/i].  And combat is nuanced but fair and brutal; it's just really satisfying combat.

I never thought I'd be recommending a rogue-like of any sort, but here I am: Get Dead Cells, play five runs, and I think you'll be hooked.

as a fan of roguelites i've often heard a lot of people say "oh have you played dead cells? that one's pretty good", so whilst it was on sale i figured i'd give it a go, but honestly most of my time in it has been put into it solely for the sake of giving it a fair shake, so i'll rattle off my pros and cons:

Pros: 
++ game was clearly made with love and there's plenty of references to other roguelites if you like that kind of thing
+ animations are very lively and full of character
+ satisfying parries (albeit maybe too forgiving)
+ SOME interesting weapons and items
+ unique modifiers can make some weapons more interesting
+ clearly some lore involved, albeit it's sparsely scattered around
+ there's a conscientiousness like the timer being frozen in shops, lore rooms and between levels present throughout most of the game
+ some okay level variety once you unlock all of the runes
+ game can feel pretty nice when you're speeding through it, and speedrunners have access to options for their gameplay

Cons:
--- super limited weapon, item and mutation pools, like, REALLY limited, there's probably as many mutations/items/weapons total as EtG has in just guns and nuclear throne can match it as well despite being a much smaller game
--- the damage type system, whilst somewhat unique for a roguelite, carves down the previously mentioned limited selection even more and shoehorns you into specific items whilst creating various build incompatibilities that hurt variety even more
-- the limited mutation pool gets limited even more by a hard limit of 3 per run, stopping you from getting ridiculous combinations you'd see in other roguelites like EtG, RoR, etc, which is then further harmed by weapon scaling not affecting the mutations that'd affect the weapon, ie, you have a bow that scales with survivability, but the arrow effects and buffs that come from it would otherwise depend on tactics mutations for their effects. similarly, a vast majority of the "brutality" skill tree mutations are locked to just melee weapons and tactics to ranged, hurting build variety even more on top of that.
-- ultimately this means that hybrid builds are essentially not viable in any way shape or form, especially since scrolls only get stronger the more points you put into them, but because mutations are all bound to specific stats, opting into any other scroll for survivability or utility purposes, ie to support your turrets or defensive gameplay for example, is kneecapped
-- boss variety is extremely limited, only having 4 in the base game
-- game can get quite repetitive, a bad sign for a roguelite
- bosses have an arbitrary damage cap of around 15% HP per hit, so even if you've got weapon mods like, "+300% damage dealt and taken", your damage will be neutered anyway, and whilst i'm familiar with boss DPS caps thanks to EtG, at least that game has some rare weapons that allow you to bypass it - having it unilaterally is a unreal wet blanket

ultimately the game seems sabotaged by its own mechanics, and whilst the lack of variety could maybe be remedied without the limitations, unfortunately they do exist and i'm not convinced i'd like to pay the game's cost all over again just for the DLC

and i've played enough to get to BSC2, so it's not like i'm inexperienced at the game

Honestly amazing game, best roguelike around imo, don't get me wrong, the game itself is hard at higher difficulties, but you can play as slow and as safe as you like, with whatever build you like, with whatever limitations you like. The dev's to this day still update with big innovations each time even this many years on. Zero in game shop or anything, everything is in-game; weapons, skins, everything. A solid game if you like platformers that reward you for good reaction time and character building but you also must be patient because you will die... a lot. The game has beautiful pixel art with a stylish world of horror, and a huge variety of skills and weapons to find. The permadeath is rough but you still keep the possibility of picking up any unlocked items that you earned on previous play-throughs and you can play harder versions of the game to challenge yourself and see new content. Once you know what you are doing you can probably beat the normal difficulty in a couple of hours or less but dying and learning how to do that is the fun of it.

It is referred to as a metroidvania, but I would not call it that exactly because it is not a big open world where you cross over the same areas and discover new things in the same playthrough. It is more linear with some branches that all go to the same place and you discover new things between different playthroughs, meaning you will die and start from scratch with only the unlocked possibilities. I really like the old metroidvanias, but the dying-and-starting-over mechanic is less fun to me so I will rate this lower. Overall it is a fast, entertaining game with solid controls and lots of strategies to try using new weapons, skills and building the character.

Few things I do not understand, are the Survival items, perks, choices, shields and heavy weapons. You pair this with a mechanic that rewards "not getting hit", "1 hit and you die" but then you add in the green Survival based items, heavy weapons and shields. Heavy weapons being so slow, you are bound to get hit and the enemies of this game being so insanely quick they can even dodge your slow heavy attacks. Shields are useful on occasion yes, but if you are gonna get hit why not...dodge roll? Parrying tends to be more risky than dodge rolling....

  I understand that perhaps the game wants players to enjoy different play styles, but at the same time it shoves in the "cursed" mechanic that basically only rewards high damage/ranged, Brutality/Tactic builds. There are a lot more mechanics and other things that also only reward that kind of play style, so why would i ever want to take Survival builds or items or mutations? Like whats the point?

Dead Cells is just a tremendously fun game.

The Good Stuff:
[list]
[*] The movement in the game feels so good. It's fast, fluid and precise.
[*] Level design is done super well. While the level as a whole is procedurally generated, the elements within are often more designed. The devs nailed it with their parameters for stitching everything together.
[*] Level design encourages a great mix of platforming and combat. Every encounter can be a puzzle.
[*] Weapon/item variety and balance is phenomenal. It's astounding how every item can have its place in a run and be viable. All it takes is the right combo of other gear and/or affixes to make my least-favorite weapon into a fun one.
[*] Combat is challenging and feels awesome to master. 
[*] Enemies vary wildly in how they approach you or how you approach them.
[*] Death feels meaningful and fair. (Usually. Rats are probably responsible for the most "WHAT?!" exclamations)
[*] The crossovers, tie-ins and easter eggs are so plentiful, there's bound to be something in here that makes you smile.
[*] Accessibility features are comprehensive and useful.
[*] Assist Mode now exists for those who want to play the game as more of a platformer than a roguelite.
[/list]

Your Mileage May Vary:
[list]
[*] This game is hard and it gets harder once you beat it the first time. I relished the challenge, not everyone does.
[*] There isn't a whole lot of plot. There's a fair bit of environmental story-telling, but it's no Dark Souls.
[*] Music is great ... until the 80th time you've heard the song for The Prisoner's Quarters. Having dedicated themes per zone will have that problem. (Castlevania DLC is worth it just for the soundtracks)
[*] There are sooo many outfits. If you like unlocking things and/or playing dress up, this game has you covered. I basically stuck with the Hotline Miami outfit once I got it because I like readable fonts for damage numbers.
[*] Once I consistently made it to the end of most runs, I found that run length averaged ~1hr.
[/list]

The Not-so-Great:
[list]
[*] All your friends will have the same advice: "git gud"
[*] Other roguelites will pale in comparison.
[/list]

I put down the final boss in only a handful of runs with a balanced build, only to realize two things primary...roughly 40% of players have this achievement, and that I haven't even scratched the surface of what this game has to offer (not including DLC)!

Now that I'm digging further into the base games deeper mechanics, I'm finding an incredible amount of depth and complexity that I didn't initially expect. I've already gotten my money's worth out of Dead Cells, but I certainly will not be putting this game down anytime soon. I'll be buying the DLC thereafter! 

Update #1
I've nearly doubled the time in the game since my initial Positive review, and my continued play time has only pulled me even deeper into this game's mechanics - the game's complexity is truly incredible, though not quickly apparent. Replaying the initial levels started to wear a bit on me early on when my focus was primarily just obtaining cells for unlocks. Now, my focus is on weapon/stat builds with mutations, and clearing these early levels without taking a single hit. Incredibly powerful builds are certainly possible, but everything comes with a cost - moving to the Custom game mode to take unwanted items out of the random drop selections came with some fun surprises, that's for sure! 

I absolutely cannot wait to delve into the Castlevania DLC, but I'm holding out until I push much further into the base game's content. I'm pushing myself to whip through the base game's content before delving into the DLC.

I'm generally not a fan of rogue-likes, but Dead Cells is the exception as my introduction to the genre. 

The countless cute and funny references to other media is always fun to come across, and adds to the charm. Adding on to that, I think the pixelated 3D artstyle is one of the reasons why I keep playing this game in comparison to one such as Hollow Knight. And nostalgia reasons, of course. 

While the game can be difficult, and lead to many moments of rage quitting after dying when you're seconds away from chipping off the last chunk of a boss' health bar, the various amount of weapons and builds you can put together makes sure each run is a possible success. I enjoy experimenting with various equipment and upgrades and at one point I made it all the way to the end of a run with only the beginner shield lol. On the whole, the game is incredibly well-balanced (the base game is at least).

The DLC is woven into the base game seamlessly, and when I first started playing I would end up on a DLC path without realising, thinking it was an alternate route. Which in a way, it kind of is, as there's is only one final boss. [spoiler] Barring the secret ones. [/spoiler]

TL;DR: Recommended as it has a unique art style and varied builds but can be frustrating.

I found myself unfortunately incapable of getting into this game. The beautiful animations and harsh but fair gameplay was simply not enough for me.

The lack of variety in the weapons was one of the main offenders in my opinion. Whenever I'd arrive at a shop, I would just walk past it as I knew that there would not be anything of interest.

I do believe that the final nail in the coffin was how the permanent upgrades never made me excited to go for another run -- A death sentence for Rogue-Likes. A good upgrade to me would be something I want to get because it encourages the style of play I enjoy. The upgrades in Dead Cells often left me thinking that they were unfathomably bland or downright useless.

I did greatly appreciate the accessibility options offered in the menu and I think that was an excellent addition from the developers, but just like with the rest, this isn't enough for me to keep playing.

My negative review represents my view of the game, not that the game is inherently bad... in fact it's inherently better than most of the incomplete games that get released these days.

My problem with this game is retention and the lack of desire to come back to it, unlike Hades. Although there are LOTS of different weapons, they all basically feel the same - mash your attack button, dodge, and keep mashing until the enemy dies... making no weapon actually feel unique... just some were worse/better than others. Hades on the other hand, each weapon combined with different boons to make each weapon feel unique. Some of those weapons were better with certain boons than others, and those weapons had different play styles even though the core of the game was still just mash attack and dodge.

The long term progression in this game is extremely slow... which can be seen as a good thing by many, giving them something to constantly work towards. But for me, the game didn't have me coming back with its base mechanic to make me want to put more hours into.

A problem I have with this game are the "kill streak/timed run" doors. I think they're bad for the game (One time I actually got BOTH on the first round so that was cool)... The reason I think they're bad for the game is... if I missed getting one of these doors on the first level I almost felt OBLIGATED to restart my run. Not because these items are necessarily needed (although not getting one of these will be a major hit in your power spike at the start of the next level), but because it just felt pretty terrible to miss. Also this is by far the biggest power spike you'll be offered during any single dungeon, you just get so much from opening one of these doors. Now, if there was comparable loot within the level where you could go "oh it's okay I didn't get this door opened because I opened up a chest that has loot on an equivalent level" that wouldn't be bad. Some people may disagree, and say that they deserve the loot for perfecting the level. I agree, you deserve something, but again missing these makes me instantly press escape and restart, totally ruining the fast paced momentum this game is supposed to be about. Some people may not care if they miss these doors and continue regardless, but for me it was an itch i had to scratch.

In yon ancient world, where the sun doth traverse the firmament and the earth beneath lay clad in the verdant tapestry of nature's handiwork, wherein myriad adventures unfold, there exists a gem of pixelated prowess known as "Dead Cells." Verily, it is with great enthusiasm that I pen this missive, extolling the virtues of a game that hath, in its essence, encapsulated the very spirit of relentless perseverance and unyielding tenacity.

From the initial foray into the cryptic corridors of the cursed castle to the tumultuous battles that ensue, "Dead Cells" doth weave a tapestry of challenge and reward. The symphony of clashing blades, the staccato of arrows finding their mark, and the resonant echoes of triumphant victories compose an opus that resonates with the true aficionado of the digital amphitheater.

Methinks the roguelike nature of the game, wherein each demise begets a wiser resurgence, doth provide an unrivaled sense of accomplishment. The procedurally generated realms, though capricious in their design, do foster an environment wherein adaptability and skill burgeon in unison. A knight errant traversing the ever-shifting landscapes, battling monstrous adversaries, is met with not only a test of mettle but an odyssey of self-discovery.

Ah, the artistry in the pixelated panoramas! "Dead Cells" bestows upon the discerning spectator a visual feast reminiscent of yore, harkening back to the golden era of 16-bit wonders. The amalgamation of nostalgia and modern design coalesce into an aesthetic symphony that doth satiate the longing for a bygone era whilst tantalizing the gaze with contemporary finesse.

The armory of weaponry and habiliments offered within the game's arsenal is nothing short of commendable. Each blade, bow, and shield exudes its own distinct flair, fostering a myriad of playstyles to suit the preferences of the valiant player. The pursuit of evermore formidable armaments becomes a noble quest in itself, an ardent endeavor that adds an enticing layer to the already rich tapestry of exploration.

Furthermore, the continuous support and updates bestowed upon "Dead Cells" by its vigilant developers is a testament to their dedication to the gaming community. The addition of content and refinements bespeak a commitment to perfection, making the game a living opus that evolves with the passage of time.

In summation, let it be known that "Dead Cells" is not merely a game; it is an odyssey, an allegory of resilience, and a symphony of pixelated mastery. Thus, with a heart brimming with enthusiasm and a quill dipped in resounding endorsement, I wholeheartedly recommend "Dead Cells" on Steam to any valiant soul seeking an unparalleled escapade through the crucible of challenge and triumph.

Dead Cells, renowned for its challenging roguelike gameplay and procedurally generated levels, unfortunately stumbles when it comes to diversity and inclusion. While the game excels in mechanics and replayability, it falls short in representing a diverse range of characters and narratives.

The pixel art aesthetic, while charming, doesn't excuse the lack of diversity in character designs. The protagonist and enemies alike seem to adhere to traditional tropes, missing an opportunity to introduce characters from various backgrounds, cultures, and identities. It's disheartening to see a game with such potential for creativity and imagination opting for a more conventional and unvaried approach.

The narrative, though minimalistic, could have benefited from including a more diverse cast with unique stories and perspectives. In a gaming landscape that is evolving towards more inclusive storytelling, Dead Cells feels like a missed chance to break away from the standard hero archetype and explore a wider range of characters.

While the core gameplay loop is addictive and the challenge is ever-present, the lack of diversity ultimately makes the game feel stagnant. In an industry that is increasingly recognizing the importance of representation, Dead Cells could have stood out as a beacon of inclusivity. Unfortunately, it remains trapped in a cycle that overlooks the potential for a richer and more varied gaming experience.

Dead Cells is fun, hard, rewarding and will make you scream like a howler monkey that stubbed its toe when you die during a good run. Not for everyone, but becomes magnificent once you learn to master your skills. This is probably the best combat centric rogue-like I've played. The various weapons you pick up can completely change the way you play the game, making each run feel like it's own individual experience. This game definitely combines a souls-like combat style with the randomly generated levels of a roguelike better than pretty much any other game out there. 

The game is smooth, has very pleasing visual aesthetic and color palettes, great animations and a lots of cool outfits. Even though they advise for  you to play with a controller, i didn't feel the need for one, prefering keyboard and mouse instead. 

The controls feel good and are fully rebindable, attacks are satisfying to land and the enemies have tells that stand out enough that taking damage doesn't feel cheap. There's a lot of platforming involved, and the map is full of secrets and powerful loot. Also, the soundtrack is a certified banger.

A complete run can last up to 1 hour, 1 hour and a half, depending on the difficulty, route and personal skill.
Dying is not bad. I repeat, DYING IS NOT BAD. This game teaches you stuff through death, and it's a great learning tool. You get destroyed by an enemy you've never seen before? Great, now you know to play safe around them or avoid them altogether.

Difficult but fair combat, tight controls. I always feel like when I die it's due to my own fault and skill. A ton of content. Countless weapons, abilities, skills, etc. to unlock and all of them feel unique and fun to use. Also a ton of unlockable cosmetic outfits. And I want to note that this game has the most extensive accessibility and gameplay options I've ever seen. You can fine tune the game to your preferred experience no matter what your skill level is.

I really wanted to like this game. I don't mind playing difficult and challenging games like Dark Souls, but this game was just too hard and stressful for me. The early levels will feel like a chore after the first few times you die. Unfortunately, there's no way to skip these levels and you have to explore them if you want enough upgrades to survive the later levels. This means wasting 20 minutes going through repetitive levels just to die at the same part over and over again. You really don't get the chance to learn the parts you died at because you're too busy going through the early levels.

The game has an incredible amount of weapons and skills to unlock, but a lot of them aren't very good except for very specific builds. You can toggle off the weapons and skills you don't like. The permanent unlocks didn't feel like they contributed meaningfully to my progress making it feel kind of pointless.

It's clearly a well made game and a lot of work went into it. But it's just not for me.

Whilst I've had enjoyed playing Dead Cells, it can be an acquired taste.
Lots of fun and certainly worth it on sale.

Dead Cells has become my go-to game for an adrenaline-packed gaming session. The pixel art visuals are a nostalgic delight, and the combat mechanics are as smooth as they come. Every weapon feels unique, and the procedural generation keeps each run feeling fresh and unpredictable.

The blend of roguelike and Metroidvania elements is executed flawlessly. The challenge is steep, but it only adds to the sense of accomplishment when overcoming each level. The continuous updates from the developers keep the content exciting, and the community engagement is commendable.

While the difficulty may be a turn-off for some, it's the heart of what makes Dead Cells addictive. Learning from each death and adapting strategies is part of the fun. The only reason I'm not giving it a perfect score is the occasional feeling of repetitiveness in level design.

Overall, Dead Cells is a must-play for fans of challenging gameplay and pixel art aesthetics. It's a game that keeps on giving, and I find myself coming back for more, run after exhilarating run. Highly recommended!

I do not like to look stuff up till I've had a few goes at figuring it out myself, but this game includes a lot of doors to DLC content that remain locked unless you have bought the DLC, but no sign that is what they are.  So now, it's happened 3 or 4 times, I've resorted to looking on wikis and such, only to learn there is no trick to figure out, other than 'Give us money'. 
I prefer the Darkest Dungeon method, where DLC content does not even show up until and unless you own that content.

Recommended for perma-stressed middle-aged men. This game will not make you any less stressed, but it will take your mind away from your original source of stress, by replacing it with the stress caused by playing (yes!). This stress is different though, because Dead Cells engages your body and soul (aka getting into the flow), leaving no room for your ordinary perma-stress, effectively giving you a relief. In addition, when you finish a good/lucky run, or discover something nice, the game will often offer a good sense of accomplishment  - a thing that rarely happens if you are perma-stressed and stuck in real life. I reckon, it is more efficient than playing games designed as peaceful and/or meditative where nothing really happens and your mind clings to your normal sources of perma-stress, like Dorfromantik (even the birds chirping were getting on my nerves there).

This game is very fun, but be aware, the difficulty level is extremely punishing. Much hard than Hades for example. I had to turn down the difficulty by quite a bit unfortunately, but to each their own.

Very good game and I highly recommend it if you like soulslike and metroidvania games. I will say a few things before you get this game. 
1. If you die, you restart back to the beginning. You get to keep some things, but mostly you will lose every item, power, and scroll you picked up along the way.
2. The game is VERY hard. Just expect to die. No matter how much health you have, you will get comboed into a pit of spikes by every monster in the game.
3. Every time you die, you learn something. Whether you die by a new enemy's attack, or die by a falling elevator, you will learn.
4. The bosses are subpar. Sure, some of them are great, but most of them lack any actual 'fun' gameplay. 

If none of that deters you, please buy this game. You can spend hours on one session and not even realize it.

A metroidvania game with randomly generated levels and perma-death. It's still in early access, but it's pretty fun!

+ Nice graphics and character animation
+ Fast and fluid movement
+ Satisfying combat
+ Many items to equip
+ Randomly generated levels and a lot of stuff to unlock give it a good replay value

- Can be too difficult at least at first, when you haven't unlocked the upgrades yet
- It seems that in later game, enemies can deal massive damage very quickly, as your main character doesn't seem to have much of so called "mercy invicibility", so that they keep taking damage constantly if you get cornered by enemies. You can literally go from full health to none in like two seconds. Just one mistake can end your run and that can feel very frustrating.

So at the beginning, the game was cool and I was hooked. But after some plays I started to understand that:

- the game has practically no story and I don't understand who the character I'm playing is and his motivation;
- the game is always the same repetition (except for some randomness in the level generation which doesn't bring me novelty enough) and I have no feeling of progress;

It's like I'm always starting the same game from scratch and I don't find this concept interesting, it doesn't entertain me, it doesn't push me forward.

It also didn't help that this was the first game I played in a long time and my first on steam since my comeback to games since years, so I was I bit naive and I didn't knew what roguelike games were (repetition), and that they mostly lack history. Two concepts I usually do not appreciate.

But ignoring the repetitive, it's good, the first gameplay and the graphics were good.

In other words, I started to like it until I realized that I don't like playing like that

I never really understood the Metroidvania craze outside the original context of Metroid and Castlevania, games that did interesting things with platforming and attack. I never thought I would spend so much time hacking and slashing away as I have with Dead Cells.

The base game is really fun and very easy to get sucked into. It's fast-paced and almost frenetic in its approach to combat. Pair that with a wide array of weapons, bonuses, and other fun things to add to your character (including some Castlevania toys, if you buy the DLC) and you have almost infinite replayability. 

Hats off to the dev team for also putting in some really entertaining easter eggs throughout the maps.

One of my main reasons for buying dead cells was because i really like the 2d animation trailers, so when i played it through the xbox game pass i was disappointed to see that the main character wasnt the one eyed guy from the trailer. Not a big deal though since you can actually unlock his head in the game. Anyways, despite that slight disappointment I was glad that the gameplay was extremely fun and quick. It feels so satisfying to get a kill each time and I love how all the weapons are balanced in a way that they're all viable. The game can feel so chaotic at times when battling, especially if your weapons has a bunch of effects, and seeing all those effects come into action feels amazing to see. I typically prefer melee weapons, but with the amount of choices this game provides I might test out bows and arrows more later down the line. ALSO DON'T UNDERESTIMATE SHIELDS these things were my SAVIORS in a lot of my runs and I shouldn't have underestimated them when first playing the game. since rolling has a cooldown, shields comes in clutch soo many times and could save you the run. 
I recently defeated the final boss and it felt soo good, but there's still so much more content and things to unlock and i cant wait to sweep through them all. I havent bought the dlc yet as of writing this but ill most likely buy it next time there's a sale or if I have time.

Dead Cells wears its inspirations on its sleeve. If you are at all a fan of classic Metroidvanias and Roguelikes, then you'll probably find something you like in this game. The references to other games come across as cheeky and fun rather than nostalgia bait, while the game manages to carve out its own identity in a rather crowded genre. A fast, fun and frenetic experience.

combat is fast paced and fun, and a large choice of weapons and abilities can make a run easier and craft your desired playstyle. the music and the visuals in this game help you slow down and appreciate the exploration. biomes have a randomized layout on each run so the game doesn't feel stale, and leaves you wondering what will happen next. the game is difficult, but fair, and has some accessibility features if needed or wanted. overall this game is a love letter to both the metroidvania and roguelike genres, highly recommend if you need an addicting and fun game

After spending over 31 hours delving into the rich, rogue-like world of 'Dead Cells,' I can confidently say that this game is a masterclass in tight, responsive gameplay and provides a challenging yet immensely rewarding experience. The game's beautifully crafted levels, paired with its satisfying combat mechanics, create a loop that is hard to put down. Each run feels unique thanks to the procedural generation and the vast array of weapons and abilities at your disposal. The difficulty is punishing but fair, encouraging you to learn and improve with each death. The art style is captivating, with environments that are as beautiful as they are deadly. 'Dead Cells' offers an exceptional balance of risk and reward, making each victory feel earned and every advancement a thrill. For anyone who enjoys action-packed platformers with rogue-like elements, I wholeheartedly recommend 'Dead Cells.' It's a game that respects the player's time and skills, and it's a title that I find myself returning to repeatedly, always discovering something new and exciting. Don't miss out on this gem!

"Dead Cells is a rogue-lite, metroidvania inspired, action-platformer."

This is the most accurate explanation for what you are getting into, gameplay-wise, but this game is also FLOWING with charm, and I know most of the people who have played this will agree. There's a story that drives the player, but doesn't take up the main focus of the game. There's witty dialogue, fun secrets; the game almost feels alive at times. I was never super into Metroid, Castlevania, or even roguelites or roguelikes. But this one? This one is one of my favorite games of all time. It hits that niche of inspiring me to get better, try harder, without making the losses feel TOO brutal immediately. It scales with your ability, each run varying completely to still give you a challenge and help keep the player engaged enough, while also introducing new elements to the play. I love this game.

I want to love this game so badly but it feels like it was designed maliciously, almost like they hate the player: here's a quick example.

Say you're having a bad run. Your first weapon wasn't great. You missed a bonus reward from not getting hit because the hole you jumped down had spikes at the bottom that you couldn't possibly tell were there. You barely scraped by and made it to a shop. You FINALLY found a good weapon. This should be the turning point, but nah. The shopkeeper was a mimic. It's as hard as a full fledged boss fight and you're already having a bad run so now you die.

Stuff like this happens all the time in this game, and it just wears you down. Every time I felt like I was having fun with the game something would happen that just ruined my run and felt strangely cheap and out of my control. There are 5 difficulty levels and after winning my first few runs and upping it to the first new difficulty, I felt like I hit another brick wall and it would take me another 20 hours to win another run. Progression is so slow and it feels like a chore to play sometimes.

I have had a lot of fun with this game. Dead Cells reminds me of one of those awesome Arcade side scrollers I would dump countless quarters into in the long long ago in the before times.
Now I get turn my quarters in for plastic and just buy the thing to have countless plays and challenge myself by turning up the heat making the game hard as nails or you can make it easy peasy lemon squeezy!

Your reward, for getting a bit further in the game, is to go strait back to the beginning, and do it all over again. The combat is clunky . Occasionally, the weapon that you are using stops your movement, and occasionally not. It is very confusing.

I have been gaslit. For ages I had been told that me criticizing "hard" games was just me having a "skill issue", that most, if not all of them, were mechanically sound and well-designed, and that my critiques were invalid. I'd been made to think difficulty by itself made games unfun for me, and that a game being hard inherently meant I wasn't going to like it.

Dead Cells was refreshing because it confirmed what I had believed to begin with. Most "hard" games just suck. This one is an exception. 

I've been a fan of roguelikes for a minute now, even being really new to the genre, having only really dived into them this year, and I can tell you firsthand that Dead Cells is among the best I've ever played. Very rarely do I feel like I get punished for things outside of my control; just about every single hit I take feels like it was completely, and more importantly, realistically avoidable. It doesn't fall into the trap that a lot of hard games do where it just throws a bunch of barely telegraphed baloney at you and expects you to know what's going to happen; every attack an enemy throws is easy to telegraph, with the difficulty coming from your ability to multitask and plan out how to avoid as many enemy attacks at the same time as possible. This, too, never falls into the realm of being realistically impossible; once again, I never feel like hits that I take are anyone's fault but my own. Hell, I rarely even get pissed at the game because of it. 

Now that's not to say the game is perfect. While I haven't been through that many boss battles, the ones I have been through have been, uh...poor. The Concierge is a total pushover until he decides being functionally invincible on occasion is a good idea, and the ninja guy I totally forget the name of is just needless projectile spam to the point of parody. It makes it extremely hard to tell what's a special effect and what's going to actually hit you, and perhaps most importantly it doesn't feel realistic to be able to dodge all of these (although I'm sure it is). Weirdly enough though, I've haven't died to either of these bosses once, though Fortnite "Ninja" Blevins did come quite close. 

All and all, while the price is a bit steep, I feel like the content is there to just about make this worth its price, especially on sale. I haven't even mentioned that the developers still regularly make content updates for the game. And I don't mean paid DLC, though that does exist, I mean free-to-everyone content updates, which is always extremely nice to see. I can absolutely see where the love and adoration for this game comes from, and even with my (currently) limited playtime, I can already tell this game is going to be a mainstay in my library for a loooong time.

rats in the sewer killed me

- The mechanic of unlocking weapons is fundamentally flawed. If each drop is randomly picked from a pool, then the bigger you make this pool, the less likely you are to get a weapon you want. This means you're actively punished for unlocking new weapons, as there is no guarantee that they are good or suit your playstyle.
- Waaay to many items are references to other games, to the point in my first runs of the game I barely saw any actual weapon from Dead Cells and most of my "inventory pool" consisted of references to other games. This is not only tiresome, but also weakens the identity of the game.  Couldn't help but roll my eyes at the 90th reference to this other game.
- Whenever people talk about Dead Cells, they highly praise the movement and controls. I think those people should play more 2d sidescrollers. Dead Cells movement/controls are nothing special. Yes, it's good, but it also has plenty of bads. Wall crawling and ledge grabbing is all sorts of weird and wonky, you don't have aerial movesets (instead you just "stand" on air while attacking), double jumping feels bare minimum to function. The few movement upgrades you get if they even quality for that don't really become part of your moveset and some of them are redundant or just lazy.
- People also often praise how this game has so many different weapons. They forget to mention how 90% of them are completely worthless, with weird ass movesets that feel like they are different for the sake of it.
- The game is incredibly short, it just takes a long time to finish. It pads itself out with repetition, grinding and permadeath masking an actually pretty short game with only very few levels not counting the DLCs. And the levels themselves are not interesting, it's just rooms of monsters with an occasional simple platforming puzzle, but as the maps are procedurally generated and the monsters randomized, there is no intent or real level design, it's just stuff mashed together without any thought put into it. The music is nice and there is some level of atmosphere, but that is ruined by the next point...
- The game doesn't take itself seriously, and doesn't take the time you spent on it seriously either. This becomes especially evident after the free DLC boss, if you had any sort of investment into this game's story, you are an idiot, and the devs don't respect the game or you. No, they're actively mocking you. It wants you to spend hundreds of hours grinding through its bullshit higher difficulties and inane crafting requirements only to give you no reason to care. It is not funny, it's not quirky, it's pathetic and childish. I bet the writers of this game think marvel quips are the pinnacle of writing and saying a lot of bad words and showing the middle finger makes for good "adult" humor.
- The way the devs throw the DLC entrances right at your face when you don't have them is what I expect from a free phone game, not something I bought off steam. If you don't have the DLCs, the entrances should not be there. This is at best nasty. Really tells you the type of people the developers of this game are.

In conclusion, don't buy this game. Yes, it has some goods, but the devs don't respect you or their own game, and I don't think you should respect them either.

Finally getting around to writing a review for this gem, from the perspective of a 5BC player.

One of the best games out there. Pinnacle of it's genre. Incredibly tight and fluid controls combined with the absolute plethora of weapons and skills allow for all manner of playstyles, from long distance ranged gameplay to becoming a tornado of death blitzing everything in your path if you have the skill for it. However, if you like to adopt that sort of playstyle (as I love to do, I think the fast paced action you can have in this game is almost unmatched), you can never get too comfortable because one slip up where you get lazy and you can easily lose 75% of your hp and suddenly you don't feel so invincible anymore, if you aren't already dead. But it is not unfair, if you lose health it's on you.

Massive amount of content and many amazing DLCs that are all worth it. The Devs are awesome, still continuing to deliver great updates and patches. Brilliant sound design, weapon and skill variety, environment design and even humour. Has only gotten better and better with time, do yourself a favour and pick it up. Can't recommend it enough.

Original Review

This is a very good game.  The controls are very crisp and responsive, and every time that I have died, I have felt like it was my fault instead of the game.  You could say that I feel like I'm fighting against the monsters and not against the game.  

I finally made it past the first two levels after two hours.  I struggled really hard against the elite archer in the middle of the second level, but when I finally beat him, it was super satisfying.  It's a great game to burn a few minutes here and there because the runs can be so short.  However, the game is good about saving where you left off, so there's no worries about needing to exit in the middle of a run.

Things this game does well:
* Tight, snappy controls
* Good progression of difficulty as you get better and progress further into the game.
* Decently good random generation of levels (they all look and feel the same, but the layouts can be slightly different)
* Good distribution of upgrades throughout a run (shop, pickups, chests (normal and cursed))

Writing this as the Steam Awards come out, so yes, it's a nomination for Labour of Love.
It says something about the quality of a game when they use it to teach games design at university... and that's how I discovered this. It's a roguelite semi-metroidvania combat platformer with a brutal but mostly fair difficulty curve, a very refined gameplay loop, and years of well-crafted updates and content. 
Death isn't an obstacle, it's a beginning here. Go out, fight, take cells, invest them or die horribly trying, learn, repeat. Succeed.

It is far more accessible to new players than it used to be, both from exhaustive updates to balance and content, but also through accessibility options that come at no mechanical penalty to use if you're struggling or just want a less controller-breaking experience. Overall, despite it literally being handed out as an assignment at first, Dead Cells is one of my favourite games of all time... and possibly other than Dark Souls the one I have cursed at the most.

Roguelikes. Love ’em or hate ’em, but they’re here to stay. Dead Cells, a Metroidvania-inspired game released in 2018, is just one of hundreds at this point. In it, you’re a nameless entity running through a twisted world for no real reason other than you just know you have to. You explore a series of interconnected levels littered with enemies, gathering new weapons and gear, learning new abilities, and spending gold on needed upgrades. And death means you start all over again.

What really appeals to me about Dead Cells is its lightning-fast pace. From the moment you launch the game you’re thrust into the world, sword in hand, trying to fight your way out. Should you perish, you’re quickly put back into your boots, with a new sword in hand, at the start. While the game never rushes you along, the only true downtime is between levels, when you’re spending your hard-earned Cells on new items. The gameplay is brisk, offering intense, fast-paced combat, yet it’s forgiving enough for those who prefer a more deliberate approach. This balance between speed and strategy creates a thrilling and engaging experience.

The game really shines in its player-driven experience. The ability to play how you want by letting you freely combine a wide assortment of weapons, items, and powers, tailors the experience to your own preferences. Granted, there’s a hefty dose of RNG involved, which will keep you on your toes. But the DIY approach adds depth and encourages experimentation. The semi-non-liner level design also provides a great sense of freedom in choice. Each level offers various paths and has many secrets to be discovered, allowing you to decide your own route and encouraging exploration, adding a necessary layer of replayability. All this ensures Dead Cells remains fresh for a long time for many playthroughs (or attempted playthroughs).

The combat has a certain je na sais quoi that makes it hit harder than similar games I’ve played. It’s a visceral feast of satisfaction with fluid animations, impactful feedback, and titillating sounds. Tight controls and sensible weight of every strike provides a hearty sense of power, making battle exhilarating as you rip and tear your way through the levels.  

While Dead Cells might seem to be just another pixelated side-scroller, it’s far from just that in its visual presentation. The art style is vibrant, the world is captivating, and it conveys great detail in its simplistic graphics. The environments and level design come together to form unique and memorable atmospheres. And with the many characters and enemies scattered across the levels, it all blends together to create a visually distinct and immersive world, proving that even with its pixelated art style, Dead Cells can rival the more graphically inclined games in terms of sheer beauty.

Perhaps the most remarkable quality of Dead Cells is its welcoming embrace to noobs. Even for those with little experience with roguelikes, like yours truly, it’s remarkably easy to pick up and get going. The game avoids overwhelming players with unnecessary mechanics, offering a gentle learning curve. Yet, it keeps you invested by introducing new elements and challenges gradually. This approach strikes a fine balance between accessibility and depth, making Dead Cells a game that can be enjoyed by both veterans and newcomers alike. All in all, a true testament to great game design.

This is as close to perfection as you can get with a rogue-like metroidvania. The movement feels crisp, the controls are responsive and the weapon feedback is very satisfying. The game also feels fair in that I felt every death was a result of my own incompetence. The shear amount of replay-ability is also crazy considering the amount of content that the DLCs have added which themselves have been highly praised. Dead Cells also achieves what few games manage to achieve, and that is that death doesn't feel too punishing. I never felt that I wasn't up for a retry. You get to restart with the possibility of getting an entirely different set of gear that you then have to adapt to. My playtime is not as high here, but I've sunked countless hours into the Android version of the game.
