Almost 3.5 years later, much of what I wrote in my original review still stands. It has become one of the definitive games in the roguelike metroidvania genre, which has now become a genre unto itself, chock full of amazing options. I never get tired of this game.  I did not expect to enjoy this game as much as I did or put as many hours into it as I have. I may put it down for a few months, but I always come back because the developers are constantly releasing new free content for it. I happily bought the paid DLC simply because of all of the free updates that they've released. I can't believe how much the game has grown and changed and become an even smoother experience. The combat is still incredibly smooth and satisfying, and the variety of weapons and biomes has only grown over time. 

Most of my deaths don't feel cheap, they were just because I got careless or cocky, or because I've hit a skill wall and need to practice more. The movement in this game is incredibly solid, giving you much-needed control over your character as you dodgeroll and slice/bash/explode/etc. your way through enemies. The variety of tactics and strategies you need to use for enemies is great and the number of weapons you get to apply those tactics and strategies are various and sundry. The game has added a ton of weapons, biomes, and enemies since release, in addition to outfits and weapons that are crossovers with some of my other favorite games, such as Risk of Rain, Blasphemous, and Terraria. 

It is admittedly rough to deal with the fact that each run is permadeath and unlike other roguelike-ish games, it doesn't give you passive/active improvements as often to carry over into future runs. In this game, unlocking new weapons and adding them to your pool or improving things such as how many times you can use your potion or how much money you get from recycling weapons are your main ways to improve your runs as opposed to, for example, passive increases in health.  [strike]These unlocks can take time, as they require the titular cells, with the passives sometimes costing in the hundreds to unlock. If you're not prepared to have some patience while progressing because you're used to swifter/differently tiered progression in other roguelikes, this may not be the game for you.[/strike] 

Dead Cells added a major accessibility update this year, which was one of the best decisions they could have ever made, that makes the above comment no longer as accurate. It makes the game playable for many more people, and that can only be a good thing. I was very appreciative of their approach to soliciting feedback from the playerbase and the fact that they worked directly with AbleGamers for input on the update. There are now various ways to adjust the gameplay with its Assist Mode, with multiple types of accommodations added. The additions are too numerous to list here, but as someone who suffers from RSI and is living with post-concussion syndrome, I'm very glad a bunch of options were added that could keep one of my favorite games playable for me. 

Way back when, I called this "one of the best action-platformers I've played in a long time". A few years later and with many more roguelikes/lites under my belt, I can safely say this is one of my all-time favorite games in any genre, period. It's a comfort game for me now, familiar enough that I can easily listen to a podcast/audiobook while I play but still requiring my focus in a way that is soothing to my brain. I'm legitimately grateful to Motion Twin and Evil Empire for creating and continuing to update this game and involving the playerbase as heavily as it does. I hope to be playing it for many more years to come.

[Edit] Another year, another update to this review. An unlikely crossover with Castlevania of all things released this year, adding new bosses, weapons, outfits, and absolutely fantastic music that isn't to be missed. The level design and art are still utterly Castlevania while giving it that Dead Cells spin. If you're a Castlevania fan, the little homages and secrets will delight you. There's another pending update as I write this to add more content focused around Cursed items/gameplay. I love that there is always something new to look forward to in this game.

I'm just writing this because I wanted to leave a scathing terrible review for the new Destiny 2 expansion, but had to check the assumption you have to own a game before being able to review it. I won't buy it, so instead I will write a much deserved recommendation for Dead Cells. Unlike Destiny, a game ruined by monetization and grind, Dead Cells gives you much more than you pay for.
For one, just look how cheap it is compared to AAA titles. There are plenty of small studio or indie games that are amazing, well worth more money, and they still charge so much less. I got this on release for PC because roguelikes are some of my favorite games, the first DLCs when they first came out, and now I have ALL the DLC and game on my phone, just because it's so nice to have whenever, wherever, and the controls are simple enough they work well on a phone, but harder content of course won't be easy with touch screen controls! Phew that was a run on sentence. You like roguelikes/rougelite? Enjoy 2D platformers and combat? Enjoy "soulslike" combat? If you said yes to all three you need to play Dead Cells, and if not still give it a try. This is the best game of its sort on steam, and on the app store. Don't look at my hours on steam, I've played plenty more on my phone.

Dead Cells is a standard. It is one of those games.
It is one of those games that you'll use as a comparison of quality for other videogames.

Dead Cells is a run based hack and slash random dungeon adventure.
Heavily inspired by the metroidvanias out there, but it is so much more than the some of it's parts.

The items and loot are unlocked slowly, the story peeks and draws you in to make you chase it, the game feels so fluid and natural to play it will feel like a classic in moments. And to top that off, it's really hard. Once you're dead, it's over. You are forced back to the start and all the dungeons layout is shuffled into something else. -and yet in that defeat, you'll still feel accomplished.

You might have found and banked a blueprint, or finally unlocked a skill rune (one of the few things you get to keep) or even discovered a new area all together and just seen it ... before you were brutally destroyed by an enemy you saw for the first time, your collection of cells exploding all over the stage.

You won't get those cells back, but failure is always an option. You'll get back there, and you'll get them this time. Just one more run.

I've been playing Dead Cells since it came out and I can honestly say it's one of my favorite games of all time. I constantly go back to it. and if you've never tried it you really should give it a shot.

- 2020 Update, I still love it.
- 2023 Started Playing again on the steam deck, still holds up. Still fun. Still love it.

This game dies and lives with its difficulty curve. For me, the progression and difficulty was perfect: Challenging and rewarding, but never frustrating. That is, until I tried beating the game on 3 Boss Cells, where I stopped playing. Until then, the game was a lot of fun with satisfying combat and exploration. So I got 40 hours of fun out of it, which is a lot of value for the prize.

The soundtrack is great, the different weapons and skills keep the gameplay varied and it's fun to try to beat the game using cheesy builds and weapons. As a minor nitpick, I think the internal balancing of weapons could be a bit better, because the game almost becomes to easy once you discover how overpowered damage reduction is. However, the game is constantly rebalanced, so you have an evolving meta of different builds and it is fun to discover new builds.

It's absolutely crazy how much support this game still gets from the developers. It has been out for many years and it's still regularly getting free content updates and constant rebalancing, which gives this a huge replay value!

Game maybe hard to get into, but once you're used to the basics, it becomes addictive. I can play runs after runs without getting bored, try new mechanics and play styles, whether it's shooting them down from afar or jumping in, one-shotting them one by one, you will never get bored. 
The devs are amazing as well. They've managed to gather many other indies and form a strong community, which, not a lot of games have managed to accomplish. They really care about this game, they keep updates coming, and they listen to their players. Not much else you can ask from a game developer. 
Overall 10/10. A great time killer and worth putting effort into.

Edit for The Steam Awards: This deserves the labor of love award every year. Devs strive to improve and expand the game in ways we could never think of.

Great Metroidvania with new content. The ability to edit the difficulty was nice for players who are terrible but still wanted to get the achievements and finish the story.

[h1]My most played Game on Steam[/h1]

Dead cells is the game that got me hooked into Roguelite/like genre. 
I first heard of it when i was watching random game play videos on YouTube, then i got it on sale. Played it every day for like 2 hrs and during the early hours it felt too difficult and would make me rage quit. Later, when i started learning the enemy patterns,weapon mechanics and the affixes the game started becoming much easier as i was familiarized how the game was functioning.The game has got few difficulties ranging from 0 BC-5 BC (BC meaning Boss Cells) with 0 BC being the easiest and 5 being the hardest difficulty.I always had fun playing dead cells either i got defeated or when I defeated a Boss, it truly is a wonderful experience when you beat a boss who you previously died to several number of times.Dead cells gives you a actual sense of progression and the satisfaction of getting good at a game.

[b] DLC's [/b]
Dead cells has 2 DLC's and few more to come i assume?. The 2 dlcs at present are : 1) Bad Seed, 2) Fatal Falls

[b]Bad Seed[/b] :
Bad Seed introduces 2 new Grassland/Swamp-ish type biomes and 1 New Boss(Early-game) : [spoiler]Mama Tick[/spoiler].
I am personally not a fan of this DLC's content (the environment and weapons), but I would say that its a good addition to the game . I would take this route if i wanted some new variety in my runs.

[b]Fatal Falls[/b] :
 Fatal Falls DLC adds 2 biomes : Fatal Shrines and Undying Shores and 1 Mid-game boss : [spoiler]Scarecrow[/spoiler].This DLC part of the game is my most favourite addition to the game.

[b]Extra Note[/b] : If you do have extra bucks to spend, go ahead and purchase the Soundtrack for Dead cells as its really beautiful and every biome's soundtrack is befitting to its atmosphere and theme.

[b]Conclusion[/b] :
Dead cells is the perfect combination of Rogue lite,Metroidvania,Platformer put in a single game you could find on Steam imo. Don't get discouraged when you get your ass kicked by some enemies in game. Only thing you need to do is [spoiler]Git Gud[/spoiler],jk.
Add this game on your wish list and try picking it up on sale, its definitely worth it.

My Rating : 10/10.

Don't think this is a hasty review and question the game's staying power. I only have 9 hours, but that's on record. I played this game... unofficially for easily more than 30 hours. What I experienced was enough for me to go legit as soon as I could.
The combat is unbelievably satisfying, the sense of humour and writing is on point, and though repetition is the name of the game here, it never ceases to be fun. If you're interested in pretty pixel art and challenging frenetic action, I cannot recommend this game enough.

Edit in 2023 - these guys just keep on going, and I'm more than happy to support that.

Dead Cells is an exceptional PC game that seamlessly blends challenging gameplay with stunning pixel art visuals. Its procedurally generated levels keep each run unique and exciting. The fluid combat system and wide array of weapons provide a satisfying experience, encouraging experimentation. The game's relentless pace and clever level design ensure there's always a reason to dive back in for one more run. With regular updates and a passionate community, Dead Cells is a must-play for fans of roguelike action games.

Dead Cells is when:
- A mouse can kill you
- You can die without jumping to another tower
- You can die accidentally tripping over thorns
- You're not losing monster cells, but your nerve cells
- You kill the boss, but you die from his abandoned and not activated mines

Dead Cells
In a world of chaos and decay,
Where death and destruction hold sway,
There is a game, so thrilling and bold,
That takes us on a journey, both new and old.

Dead Cells is the name, and it's a game of might,
Of battles and fights, that last through the night,
Of jumping and dodging, and slicing with swords,
Of traps and enemies, that make us work towards.

The game is a challenge, so hard to beat,
With enemies that swarm, and bosses that cheat,
But we keep coming back, for the thrill of the fight,
For the rush of adrenaline, that comes with each plight.

We collect power-ups, and upgrade our gear,
To make our way through, without any fear,
We learn from our mistakes, and push ourselves more,
To see how far we can get, before the next door.

And yet, amidst the chaos and the strife,
There is a beauty, that's hard to describe,
In the graphics and the music, that play throughout,
And in the satisfaction, that comes with each bout.

Dead Cells is a game, that's hard to put down,
With its challenging gameplay, and its sights and sounds,
It takes us on a journey, both thrilling and new,
And keeps us coming back, for more adventures to pursue.

I waited to write my review until they had a completed product although I could have written this after their last major patch. The game was definitely rougher when I first started playing many months ago and there was a patch or two that I didn't like, but the latest version is a complete joy to play. It does a great job of balancing rogue-like elements within a metroidvania genre that I've always loved. 

The gameplay is fairly simple, but there is so much room for learning and growing your skills at the game with every play. The vast majority of my deaths haven't felt cheap. Most are simply due to stupidity and/or lack of skill on my part. You learn what works for your play style, how to approach different mobs, and can experiment with many different weapon combos. The replayability is off the charts in my opinion. This game is, by far, one of my favorite games to come out in quite some time. Worth a buy for sure.

Edit: I continue to come back to this game over others and have logged more than 150 hours. There's enough new items and progression to keep me interested in coming back over and over with the promise of new content and interesting changes. Also, this is my annual labor of love nominee. Greatest game ever.

Dead Cells (by Motion Twin) is a brutal roguelike metroidvania, with beautiful pixel art and an amazing soundtrack composed by Yoann Laulan. With a large variety of weapons, skills and outfits, and the fact that each level is somewhat randomly generated provides replayability. You earn cells by killing enemies, which you can trade in (between levels) to craft permanent upgrades and blueprints that you gather, reducing the effect of death. The DLCs also add plenty of extra content, with the most recent one (Fatal Falls) including 3 new areas and a new boss-fight. 
--FINAL VERDICT--
[b] 9/10 [/b]

I can for the first time say that a perfect game exist.
That is not to say that this is a game for everyone or that is the best game ever made. It IS a perfect game because everything it sets out to acomplish, it does flawlessly. From the fluid and fast-paced combat, the balance and risk-reward factor of the weapons, the satisfying gameplay loop that encourages constant replayability and evokes that "just one more run" feeling, the challenging but fair difficulty, to the amazing music and breath-taking pixel art.
All in all, an excellent game that is bound to become a timeless classic and a standard for all future action platformers, rogue-lites and metroidvanias.

I benefited from buying this game very late in its lifecycle where more than a few DLCs had dropped improving balance in the game and adding a lot of fun content.  I'm eager to see what the final DLC will bring!  On a side note I was blown away by the fact they're actually making a tv show based on the game.

If you like roguelikes, this is definitely one to add to your collection.

A really entertaining and challenging game. Prepare to die (a lot) in Dead Cells. This game is funny and entertaining. However, due to the lack of lore and the very scarce pieces of info that we find scattered through the levels, it's narratives feels shallow and empty. This results in a game that dosen't tempt me to try to replay it once I've beaten it's final boss (I'm still into it. You're gonna get it, Hand of the King. Do you hear me!?) In regard with this point I think that the devs tried to emulate the narrative style used in Dark Souls, but it still needs some improvements. In conclusion, although I think this game lacks enough incentives to want replay it, it's a fun and challenging game that evolved A LOT during in beta, and I'm sure it will keep improving in the future. In addition, the developers are always responsive to feedback from the community, and they also are open to new ideas :D

Addendum: Moving forward 4 years I'm still loving this game. I need to get past 3 Boss cells difficulty and get to the new biomes

Title: "Roguevania Bliss: Dead Cells Delivers a Masterclass in Replayability"

Review:

Dead Cells is a relentless, exhilarating journey that seamlessly blends the best elements of roguelikes and Metroidvanias, creating a gaming experience that's both punishing and deeply satisfying.

From the moment you take control of the nimble protagonist, you're thrown into a procedurally generated labyrinth filled with grotesque creatures and challenging foes. The combat is precise, demanding skill and strategy as you navigate through intricate levels, uncovering hidden secrets and unlocking new weapons along the way.

One of Dead Cells' standout features is its fluidity. The controls are razor-sharp, and the responsive gameplay ensures that every death feels fair. The permadeath aspect might seem daunting at first, but it's this very element that keeps you coming back for more. Each run feels like a chance for redemption, and the thrill of discovering new weapons and abilities adds a layer of excitement to every playthrough.

The game's pixel art is not only visually stunning but also serves as a testament to the attention to detail that went into its design. The atmospheric soundtrack complements the dark, foreboding tone of the game, immersing you in its mysterious world.

What truly sets Dead Cells apart, however, is its replayability. The procedural generation ensures that no two runs are ever the same, and the vast array of weapons, skills, and power-ups allow for countless playstyles. The constant sense of progression, even in the face of defeat, is addictive and keeps you hooked for hours on end.

The developers have been incredibly supportive post-launch, regularly introducing updates and new content that breathe fresh life into the game. It's evident that the team behind Dead Cells is passionate about their creation, and it reflects in the overall quality of the experience.

In conclusion, Dead Cells is a must-play for fans of challenging roguelikes and Metroidvanias. Its tight controls, captivating pixel art, and endless replayability make it a standout title in the genre. Embrace the challenge, hone your skills, and revel in the satisfaction of conquering the ever-shifting, hostile world of Dead Cells.

This game is simply a Masterpiece.  No debate at all.  

As mentioned by the overwhelmingly positive reviews posted, this is one of the greatest games you could play or even have sitting in your Library.  Its sheer presence alone will improve your life even if you never play it.  

I won't delve into game play mechanics or things of that nature.. it has been talked about extensively before in great detail.  What I will say is that it will be challenging but very rewarding.  Similar to a Souls-like game, its wants you to win and get better.  This game entered my life at a very difficult time and after not touching a video game for well over ten years at this point, I was immersed entirely in this experience.  I have died in this game Waaaay More than I have succeeded.. However, you will start each new run with potentially some new items, upgrades or even just better playing skills in general.  Initially starting out, I could barely even get past for the first few biomes, let alone finish a run or even defeat a boss.  At this point, in a short period of time due to the need to decompress from life, I have put in many hours of gameplay.  Filled with emotions ranging from joy, excitment, sadness, devestation and the desire to get better.  Each run contains one if not all of those emotions at certain points (losing two blueprints 3/4 into a run at the bank on 3BC is ROUUGHH).  Yet somehow the inner deep seeded desire to run it back and be better remains intact and possibly grows stronger.  
It's a rouge-lite game, there are many like it.. Its a metroid-vania style game, there are many like it.. But this one is special. I like to think of it as a Super-Sayian simulator almost (makes me feel old remembering the OG days).. You die and you come back stronger.  Games like Hades and Enter the Gungeon have given me similar experiences and are exceptional games that I have thoroughly enjoyed.  Dead Cells is special in its own right and I'm blown away that it still gets updated to this day.
After playing this game at a friends house for a weekend a while ago, I became mesmerized. The moment I got the opportunity, I purchased this game full price with the DLC's (I highly recommend to fully support the devs) without hesitation even on a  some-what limited income.  It's been an Amazing experience to say the least..So Here it is! To many more hours of Happiness and Devestation in the future, just to run it back one more time.

It's a difficult start, you need a little bit of agility to enjoy all that this game has to offer, but once you break that barrier it's one of the most fun games I've tried in terms of movement and skill set. Besides all this it has an excellent variety of scenarios and a very nice pixel art. You should definitely try it.

Small edit, to state that playing this game on Steam deck is pretty cool.

90 hours later:

This is still one of the best games I've played year after year.

Dead Cells is one of the most challenging games i have ever played. It doesn't hold your hand trough the entire game, on the contrary, it lets you freely experiment with it's vast arsenal of weapons and skills, letting you play the game as you see fit. That is why getting to the later stages and overcoming all the challenges you deemed impossible the first time around is so satisfying and rewarding. The gameplay, the general feel and flow of combat and structure of the levels all come together to create a truly innovative and challenging rogue-lite. This is further enhanced by the absolutely phenomenal soundtrack by Valmont. The OST perfectly fits with each level, making every level more distinct from the last. And to top it all off, the consistent updates from the developers, who even after all these years are still managing to add new and exciting ways to keep the game fresh even for long time veterans of the game. With all that said, this game is a must-have for any fan of rouge-style games.

An addicting, action pact, visually striking adventure where you make your way through horde of enemies all with unique abilities and ways of thwarting you. That is how I would described this game.

Starting with the most basic mechanics. The movement and combat feel crisp and extremely responsive, the input lag is minimal/none existent. The ability to customise every detail of you character each and every run make the game offer quite a lot of replay-ability, however that can be said about every rouge-lite(like) so what sets Dead Cells apart?

Starting off with extensive library of abilities, utilities, and weapons which the player has access to and that grows and expands as the player continues to explore. Along side these combat oriented things, you'll find several different costumes to re-skin your character -- some being references to other popular video games. Why this is important is because of one reason, the fact that some of the costumes have actual use in the game and can help the player unlock new areas/worlds.

Speaking of worlds, the shear amount of levels all utilising different types of level design and ways to lead players forward while still keeping true to their ground principles is amazing work. From the smallest detail always fitting, to the choice of enemy abilities working perfectly in combination with the level they're featured on is something few games accomplish.

Dead Cell quickly became game I hold in high regards after giving it a 2 hour test drive on PS5, it's a game I enjoy boasting about just as much as I love playing it.

An Unforgettable Roguelike Masterpiece!

Dead Cells is nothing short of a gaming marvel! This game has captured my heart and soul in a way that very few others have managed to do. From the moment I picked it up, I was hooked, and it has only gotten better with time.

The first thing that strikes you about Dead Cells is the exhilarating gameplay. The fluidity and responsiveness of the controls are a testament to the developer's commitment to perfection. The combat system is an absolute joy, and every swing of your weapon feels powerful and satisfying. The adrenaline rush you get as you face hordes of challenging enemies is unparalleled.

What truly sets Dead Cells apart is its roguelike elements. The procedurally generated levels keep each run fresh and exciting. Every death feels like a learning experience, and you'll find yourself coming back for "just one more run" repeatedly. The sense of progression is brilliantly balanced, and you'll constantly discover new weapons, abilities, and items that make every playthrough unique.

The art style and pixel art graphics are stunning. The dark, gothic atmosphere of the game world is perfectly complemented by the detailed character and enemy designs. The visuals create an immersive and captivating experience that pulls you deeper into the game's lore.

The soundtrack is a masterpiece in its own right. The haunting melodies and the pulsating rhythms create an atmospheric backdrop that perfectly matches the game's tone. It's a soundtrack that will stay with you long after you've put the game down.

Dead Cells also offers a variety of gameplay styles, allowing you to tailor your character to your preferred playstyle. The multitude of weapons and abilities ensures that you'll never run out of ways to experiment and strategize.

The community and developer support for Dead Cells are outstanding. Regular updates and new content keep the game fresh, and the community engagement is second to none.

Dead Cells is a game that will captivate you from the moment you start playing and won't let go. It's a roguelike that sets the gold standard for the genre, with exceptional gameplay, beautiful art, and a killer soundtrack. It's a must-play for any fan of action, adventure, and challenge. If you haven't experienced the thrill of Dead Cells, you're missing out on one of the greatest gaming experiences of our time!

[i]Warning: If you plan on playing this on the steam deck, beware that the input subsystem on the native SteamOS version is utter garbage. It can be overcome on lower difficulty settings, but as soon as you go for higher difficulties, the game becomes legit unplayable. I [u]do not recommend using it until the input code is entirely overhauled[/u] for the native SteamOS version. Use the windows version, via the Proton compatibility layer; it's so much better coded it feels like lowering the difficulty by one or two cells...[/i]

[b]Do I recommend Dead Cells?[/b]

[b]Short answer, yes with an if; long answer, no with a but.[/b]

My review is a positive one because not only most people want a short answer, but I also wish to support the indie studio Motion Twin with their work, choices and setting a good example of how video game studios could work.
Dead Cells is fun. It is extra fun, if you like the genre (platformer rogue like with unlockables), and even more so if you like the style (32bits 2D graphics with modern processing; CD quality audio with medieval inspired music).
But it is also frustrating. And it can be VERY frustrating.

So short answer, if you like rogue likes with unlockables, can deal well with frustration, do not mind the rather high asking price, and possibly like the style; by all means, go for it. 

[b]Now, let's get to the longer, "no with a but" part:[/b]

So, why would I not recommend Dead Cells; if it is fun, assuming it is done without too many bugs?
Well, the main reason lies in the way the game is developed: the developer is a small French indie studio, in which every member is equal. While I respect and salute the initiative, it shows a clear community-oriented mentality; which could be a good thing, but unfortunately has some pretty important drawbacks:

[u][b]While not marked as such, Dead Cells is effectively an Early Access game.[/b][/u]

The reason for that is very simple: the studio listens to the community a lot. A real LOT. Again, this isn't necessarily a bad trait, but it definitely gives the game a much less stable gameplay, and much less stable overall experience.
So if you pick Dead Cells, you can reasonably expect your experience to change, sometimes drastically, after any update.
For example, the recent update (1.1 - AKA pimp my ride) has angered a lot of players, and even if it has IMHO improved a lot of things, it has unquestionably made the game harder.

Some changes that made the game harder were:
[list]
[*] extreme nerfing of the damage reduction items and skills
[*] elites are more dangerous (they have more skills, like beams or shields)
[*] enemies with a shield cannot be stunned anymore
[*] item stat rerolls got more expensive
[*] the YOLO mutation (get a "free" death once) does not allow the player to pick another mutation once used (hence making it pretty useless)
[*] some HP buffs prevent the character from healing in some ways (looking at you "dead inside")
[*] ...
[/list]

Those changes are not necessarily all bad, but the amount of them coupled with them touching the essence of the gameplay; makes the game feel a lot less "released", as the game is being heavily modified regularly.

Now the other main reason why I would not recommend to buy the game is the fact that while the studio is listening to the community when adding features or re-vamping the experience, they do much less when it is about fixing bugs.
[strike]There is still no way to adjust the deadzone of a joypad, and as a result the character randomly faces the wrong direction, which in a game where it is important to kill enemies fast, is a HUGE drawback.[/strike]
Also, when the character is about to die, or the explorer trait activates, the game laggs by about one second, which usually means you take damage (in the former case, it means you can never dodge if an enemy is about to kill you, and you always die anyway...)

So, if you want a polished, consistent experience with your games, I would not recommend it, but stay tuned in case the developers eventually chill about modifying the game and start fixing the bugs.

I realise it's very late into Dead Cell's lifespan to be posting a review but this is a game that deserves some words so I'll happy add my thoughts here.

I bought Dead Cells while I was waiting for Rogue Legacy 2 to launch. I played it a bit around the first three biomes (levels), movement and dodging felt good, initial weapons were a touch underwhelming, parry mechanic didn't feel like there was a lot of feedback or benefit to it, music was good and the art style looked a bit gritty but stylish. The game's sense of humour and hinted-at background lore reminded me of Hollow Knight. The art stye choices made some creatures or attacks feel a bit obscured but all-in-all I was glad to own this and could see it being a pleasant and competent distraction, well worth the cash I'd dropped on it.

For one reason or another, I didn't play it much. Rogue Legacy 2 dropped and I sunk time into that instead as it's art style was much clearer and the gameplay more immediately engaging. 

After finishing RL2 on my Playstation (a great game and available on Steam, check that one out too), I saw an update for Dead Cells that made me salivate - Return to Castlevania. I bought this, enabled the castlevania soundtrack and suddenly, Dead Cells clicked for me. The addition of the music and some call backs to games I knew gave me enough interest to spend a little more time in Dead Cells and I have to say, I was a fool for putting this one aside.

Dead Cells isn't an immediately engaging game and instead grows over time to hook you deeper and deeper into it's systems, combat options and exploration. In the first few playthroughs, you'll get the sense that it's a quality game with a lot of love and care put into it, but it might not really grip you in the way other Metroidvania styled roguelikes can do. The deeper and more fulfilling gameplay is largely emergent here - Dead Cells tries to teach you the basics of play with simple beginning weapons, an easy first two levels and some mysterious story beats, humour or objects here and there. The more you play Dead Cells, the deeper it's hooks get into you.........then you blink and it's 2AM and your Wife is shouting "when are you coming to bed?"

Don't be like me and miss out on a fabulous experience - buy Dead Cells and give it more than a couple of hours to settle on you. As you unlock more and more items to appear in your runs, as you kill bosses and take more movement options on, as more biomes become available for you to explore, you'll realise that the early hours don't even scratch the surface of this gem. Late game, Dead Cells seems to evolve again, becoming as much about the strategy of picking biomes to match the opportunities that your item pool RNG has given you. 

If you like action-platformers, Metroidvanias or roguelike platform games Dead Cells is simply a MUST BUY. I'm a fool for not giving this more time and I intend to correct that mistake. I'm teaching my wife to play so we can do relay-runs and she might understand how addictive this little game can become. 

Last thing: If you are a Castlevania fan and you are done with Bloodstained, Get this, get the Return to Castlevania DLC and have a blast - the Death and Dracula boss fights are wild and the music is always on-point. Maria's cat is brilliantly OP when combined with the Mushroom Boi pet. Don't worry - that statement will make sense to you after you've put a couple of hours in, I promise. :)

As my first roguelite experience, it comes as no surprise that this game is a fantastic intro to the genre.

I'm still not 100% sold on the roguelite genre but that's not on the game because Dead Cells does an amazing job teaching you the value in dying and trying again, especially during your first few succesful runs.

This game is truly remarkable, and I applaud Motion Twin for their efforts in the design and creation of the game.

First, the positives.
The game is really fun. I love rogue-likes and metroidvania games, and this smacks it out of the park.
I think I find the game so fun because of the amazingly designed combat combined with the strategic aspect of finding synergies between your weapons for peak efficiency.
The game is really re-playable. With other rogue-like games, (e.g. Hades) I find that it can become quite repetitive and you can lose the motivation to play continuously unless you really like working towards far off upgrades. Unlike Hades, for example, Dead Cells offers lots of customisation and unique things that make the game a refreshing experience each time you start a run. Firstly, there are heaps of weapons to unlock and use, each requiring the player to buy them with Cells. Then, there are the upgrades, which are also bought from Cells at the Collector. The upgrades are really good in giving a more permanent change to each run, really making you feel like you're progressing. Then, there's the runes you can unlock, permanently allowing you to visit new biomes and secret areas that you otherwise wouldn't be able to go to. This is a really neat way of adding huge amounts of content without overwhelming a new player, as runes are rare and hard to find.
Then lets talk about the biomes. The biomes are absolutely amazing and are completely randomly generated, giving a whole new experience to each run, so you never see the same thing twice.
Also, theres new content updates and fixes all the time, and it's great to see the devs haven't left it behind.

Negatives:
- There's a lot of DLCs which have to be bought to experience the game fully. I suggest if you want to get the most enjoyment out of the game, they are worth a look because they add lots of new biomes, and again, lots  of replayability. Unfortunately they cost a bit of money.
- It sometimes can be frustrating if you are struggling to get blueprints to buy upgrades and weapons that you want. Unfortunately, there's nothing you can really do about this except play daily challenges which I think award you with a blueprint when you finish it...
- It's currently not co-op or multiplayer. It would be really cool if multiple players could do runs together and fight bosses together, and I think it would be a really good addition to the game, but unfortunately it doesn't look like multiplayer is going to be added to Dead Cells, which is a real shame.
- There's a high skill floor. By that I mean it can be hard for new players to pick up the game, and it will take many tries to get your first win. Just keep in mind that as soon as you pass that skill level to beat the game once, you will probably be able to beat it again and again. Great thing is, there's a virtually limitless skill ceiling, meaning your expertise in the game can always improve. Additionally, you can add more Boss Stem Cells to your run to increase the difficulty, therefore increasing the skill floor needed to beat the game on that difficulty. (I kinda turned that negative into a positive, but the game's just so good I can't think of much bad things to say about it...)

Aside from that, I can't think of much other negatives about the game. It's really well done, and a polished game. It's rare to find bugs, and generally they'll be patched quickly.

Dead Cells is a really good game, and I strongly suggest giving it a try.

(I don't thumb down non-scam games anymore. The sentiment probably still holds true though)

I deleted my save for the version 1.0 and after one hour I have to admit that I really did forget how sluggish and frustrating the beginning of the game is. 

I finished the game during EA. And now I don't want to even beat the first boss (which is virtually unbeatable if you have nothing more than the first sword). More items unlocked right away would have been much more pleasant. 

Really survivability should not be so dependent on the time spent on the game and its unlocks. The amount of souls required for some key unlocks is downright ridiculous. 

Take Binding of Isaac as example, if you are skillful enough, you can beat the game on your first try with a new save and unlock tons of new stuff on the way. That absolutely not how it feels with Dead Cells where progression plays a huge factor on your survability. Additionally, death can be huge step back on your progression if you are holding a lot of souls which just add insult to injury.

It's a different approach, I can understand that. But when you don't have much time available, this structure can feel so frustrating at the beginning. To the point that I really don't enjoy the game anymore nor that I can't recommend the game anymore.

I know my playtime doesn't look like much, but I have played this game on Xbox and on Mobile for collectively over 700 hours and have now purchased it for PC as well. I can't say this game's praise loud enough. This game has everything I need in a roguelike. Very challenging, incredibly satisfying and fast-paced combat that goes hand-in-hand with the game's solid platformer elements, gorgeous backdrops, a great soundtrack with some real bangers, crisp sound design (that dinging crit noise is a massive dopamine injection), as well as tons of secrets, easter eggs and references to other classic franchises that can easily take you over 200 hours of gameplay just to see them all. The game has a simple yet very rewarding affix system which allows you to create new synergies every run, is run by passionate developers that keep on dishing out fantastic content (the DLCs especially!), has an intriguing world and story, a very high skill ceiling and a custom mode if you just want to play with your favourite weapons or tweak your run in some creative ways as well as an accessibility mode for players who want a casual experience without much stress. In addition to all that, there is a huge amount of unlocks in the game that require you play on higher and higher difficulties just to get them all. Every single one of the unlockable weapons all play differently, and unlockable mutations give you additional upgrades you can equip in between stages. Even after unlocking every weapon, item and outfit in the base game, there's fun daily runs (which also grant you weapon unlocks), boss rush (with even more unlocks, arguably the most challenging to get in the game), and so-called "aspects" that alter the game significantly by giving you some really overpowered and fun abilites to play around with. Easiest 10/10 of my life. 

I forgot to add: This game runs smoothly on pretty much everything, so yeah, go get it

Somehow I haven't written a review for this game yet... but I think it's safe to say Dead Cells is my game of the year for 2023. (Okay so that isn't true anymore, but Dead Cells is my 2nd best game of the year. Sea of Stars beat it lol. Sorry.)

Technically, I began playing it in 2022.. but it was for under 2 hours and then I stopped. As the new Castlevania DLC was coming out in March 2023, I was thinking then would be a good chance to pick the game back up and give it a better chance. After all, I didn't hate the game. I just stopped playing it for some reason (a strange trend I do when I start a game then proceed not to play it for an extended period of time)...

Regardless, about the game. Every part about it is absolutely delightful. The gameplay? Fun and challenging. Winning battles feels rewarding and even when you lose, you're still learning. The weapons? Fun to use. I was a brutality enjoyer when I first started, then I slowly started sinking into the survival class. I've never been a fan of tactics unfortunately... But the game is pretty balanced for the most part. You can also turn on some features to make the game a little bit more attuned to your tastes, to help you ease into the harder difficulties. When I started 5BC, I had been using the cursed chest aspect, but slowly overtime I began to stop using it (I wanted to be able to get gold costumes lol).

The amount of items that there are in this game comes nowhere close to what a game like The Binding of Isaac has (literal thousands of hours), but it also doesn't have a shortage of items. I'm 139 hours through playing and I still haven't found all the items (where's the ukulele!?). I know I could just use the item made to get blueprints guaranteed, but it doesn't feel as nice then. But it's always there if you ever want to get all the items.

The diversity in areas? Amazing! Of course if you don't own the DLC's, you'll only be going through the same one or two paths over and over. But with the DLC's, it offers you so many different paths to take and of course, all the other stuff DLC's have to offer. If you haven't picked up Dead Cells, I would suggest getting the DLC's with it. It makes the game so much bigger in so many different aspects.

And the music.. OH, the music. It wasn't as great as something like The Messenger, Hades, or Omori in something I would listen to again, but the music absolutely does not disappoint. And the Castlevania OST as well? Even more fantastic! I actually prefer using that one. The music on Fractured Shrines with the Castlevania OST on is my favorite track. Next to the music in the spoiler biome as well.

I'm pretty sure there's a LOAD of categories I'm missing about this game, but that just shows how much there really is to it. Just.. get Dead Cells. You won't be disappointed. I surely wasn't.

It really is one of the best roguelike-Metroidvania games I've ever played. The excellent musical score, amazingly responsive controls, huge variety of weapons, challenging bosses - the developers have really just put everything together in an amazingly tight package.

Props on the longevity of support, too - the game came out 2018, and there's a new free content patch that just entered beta testing this week.

Dead Cells has over 100 weapons, each fitting into at least one of the following categories: Brutality / Tactics / Survival. Brutality weapons tend to be fast, but hit for smaller amounts (swords and daggers, mostly), Tactics are almost all ranged weapons (bows, crossbows, and whips, mostly), while survival weapons are almost all hard-hitting, very slow weapons (mauls, hammers, etc.) Many weapons fall under two categories (for instance, most crossbows are both tactics and survival), so that you can wield multiple weapons using a single upgrade path.

You've also got two slots for skills, which follow the same rules as weapons, but can be anything from traps, buffs, magic attacks, or pets. Pets are handy because (with the exception of the Owl) you can just summon them at the start of a level and let them do their thing. Most of the other skills are more powerful, but require you to actually remember to use them when they're available to get the most utility out of them - which can be a problem in the hectic frenzy of combat that is Dead Cells.

Everything in Dead Cells, from the music to the timed doors at the end of levels, pushes you to be a whirlwind of destruction, endlessly running forward to kill everything before you. It's actually not a horrible strategy - if you can accomplish it without getting hit.

Dead Cell's major claim to fame is it's extended game - specifically, its system of Boss Cells. Acting as a New Game+ system, each time you win the game under an increased number of Cells, you unlock a new Boss Cell. These increase the difficulty of the game - mostly by introducing harder enemies and reducing and/or removing the healing stations between levels. However, they also increase the number of scrolls available (which can drastically increase the damage of your weapons) as well as unlock how many cells can be spent on the Forge, which can increase the potency of weapons that you find on a run.

It's pretty much the perfect game for when you just want to go balls-to-the-wall killing some dudes for half an hour. Expect most runs to end in failure, but those runs that do not are some of the most amazing adrenaline highs you'll ever experience.

First off, I just like to preface that I've replayed this game many times over the years and this game is the perfect rogue like experience where its hard as balls, but every death felt justified and earned as it was mostly my fault. Also the development team has accomplished so much considering how small the team is and this game sets a very high bar when it comes to metroid-vanias and souls-likes and it really sets itself apart from all the others.

Great game overall.  The majority of the gameplay progression is exploring levels and finding items to better defeat enemies and bosses.  The player has some agency in routing through the dungeon by picking pathways that lead to predetermined "biomes" (i.e. If one wanted, one could go through the poison swap every run or the castle gates etc.).  The gameplay itself is very rewarding, with items and weapons all feeling fairly unique and having mechanics that encourage a certain style of play on a per item basis.  For example, the Baseball Bat deals more damage to stunned and rooted foes, so you seek out items that can stun and root foes, making combat be a setup for combos.  Simple but effective. 

I think most people who enjoy roguelites in general would enjoy this game.  If that's you, then give it a go. The DLC is not required to enjoy the base idea of the game, but they absolutely enhance the experience if you find the base game enjoyable. 


This below is mostly just a rant, which is not well written and you can reasonably ignore. I just had to b*tch:

My biggest, and really only, gripe is the platforming.  Most of the times it is benign, mostly acting as a medium to facilitate the combat more interestingly.  At other times there are small, mandatory platforming sections throughout levels that can be fairly dangerous, but these are mostly manageable as well.  However, there are some "optional" platforming sections one needs to complete to unlock additional items or to obtain additional scrolls that increase your damage.  And I write "optional" because I can't imagine the game expects me to NOT attempt to get the "fancy dinner jacket" outfit for my character.  Furthermore, on higher difficulties, not going out of your way to grab additional damage scrolls can make the run significantly more difficult, especially since damage scales exponentially in this game. The game does not offer really any items to affect one's platforming ability, so one just has to be good at the game, which is fine in its own right.  But I'm not playing Super Meat Boy where I can just retry a level.  Some runs take me, and I might just be a poor player, 30 to 50 minutes to get back to these "optional" sections.  And the game isn't a necessarily difficult platformer like SMB either, but it is just infuriating to lose a long run because I missed an unintuitive jump too many times.  And I have only died perhaps a few times to each "optional" section compared to bosses or mobs, but it is exceptionally demoralizing comparatively.  Get rid of this crap, man.  If the items don't really affect my ability to complete some challenge in a *roguelite* then that challenge shouldn't exist or should not be able to jeopardize my run.

Dead Cells is an absolutely great game, however it does have a few flaws.

The game itself is incredibly difficult (or it may just be the fact that im bad at video games), as it took me 250 runs to beat the Hand of the King (final boss) in normal mode. Getting to the hand, is no easy task, as you will have to go through a series of difficult biomes filled with deadly enemies (and jam-packed with a bunch of items from bows to shields to swords and even grenades). Bosses are one of the easier elements of the game however. For example, the first boss you encounter, the Concierge is very easy to dodge and predict its attacks. Dead Cells is a great game that requires practice, if you want to even get far. The rogue-like element to the game makes it one of the most punishing games i have ever played. I would highly recommend this game if you love raging at games, and feeling a sense of accomplishment when you reach a place you never had before.

The dev's passion is commendable and no doubt the game is loved by many. This is a personal problem and I want to make that clear from the start. 

The enemies aren't fun to fight against. I cannot comprehend the way they move and attack. There are no wind-ups for most of them and the devs use the exclamation mark as indication. I don't wish to condemn their capabilities but relying on an "!" leads me to believe they know the issue as well. 

Seeing a tiny "!" in a room filled with many types of enemies, with the explosion of colors and particles the game showers the screen with just doesn't feel fun. 

Another issue I have is there are no "items". Almost all games in the genre have items that modify many aspects of a run but in this one, it is only ever gear. Weapons and tools. No items. There is nothing to look forward to in a run. you got a nice weapon? You won't be looking at anything else. 

No wonder they lean so heavily towards speedrunning. And I have nothing against speedrunning. This is just an observation. There is just nothing worth finding in the areas.

In the end, the game just doesn't feel fun for me.

I have realised that this game's gameplay loop becomes very boring and repetitive after a while. The difficulty is fun at first but becomes extremely tedious when you put in an hour and a half of work in one run only to have it thrown away because you made one slip-up. This is not a skill issue, it's just boring after some time. There is an assist mode but using it makes you feel like you're cheating and defeats the game's central hook even when making minor changes. This is currently the second-most-played game in my library and I am leaving a negative review. This game gets stale like many other roguelikes. The core gameplay is fantastic but there isn't enough variety and the DLCs are underwhelming.
Note: This was written with 85 hours of play time.

What is Dead Cells? It's, like, a roguelike souls-like metroidvania-like, like you know? Modern buzzwords aside, Dead Cells is an action platformer with procedural levels that grant you infinite replayability. It's one of the best platformers with the smoothest movement, the most epic combat and some of the most beautiful 2D pixel graphics out there. It's refreshing to see a developer try and innovate on oldschool visuals like this, just shows how far we've come. This game has also taken huge inspiration from classic games and learned all the lessons of the days of yore, taking this knowledge and combining it with modern technology and experiences to create something classic but polished and approachable. It's like the ideas of classic action platformers finally realized to perfection. 

Dead Cells can be brutally difficult, but considering how fluid the amazing combat is and how crisp the controls are, it's a pure test of skill. If it gets too intense, don't forget to just stop for a bit to take in the beautiful art and amazing music. Hell, I wasn't really a fan of Metroidvanias, Souls-like games or 2D platformers in general going into this, but this game is so good, I loved it anyway and it changed my mind on all of those. I feel like with this experience, I might try and conquer an actual Souls game now, and maybe a Hollow Knight or Shovel Knight on the side. Until then, I will always know that I have one of the best roguelikes on the market to fall back on.

P.S. After you inevitably get seriously invested and then seriously addicted to this game, research the lore! It's kind of hard to experience it within the game itself because of the random dungeons and difficulty, but Dead Cells has some of the most fascinating lore ever! And a very shocking twist near the end too! So research it separately, it's worth it!

An absolutely phenomenal game.  The combat is tight, fluid, varied, and satisfying as hell.  There is such a huge variety of weapons. The potential combinations are ridiculous.  The enemies are fun to kill.  The difficulty curve is excellent.  The number of secrets and unlocks and different paths is insane.  

I started playing this game right when it was just first in early access so many years ago.  It has always maintained its excellent gameplay at the core but continuously added quality content.  Sometimes paid and sometimes free.  I have the majority of the DLC and I also own the game on Switch.  Worth it.  I still keep coming back after years.

If you're even remotely into these types of action dungeon crawlers you will 100% enjoy this game.  Even if you aren't normally there's a good chance you'll still like this one.

Boring indie rubbish. Stages are randomly generated, making them lousy and forgettable, with no true design. The "music" is droning with no real melodies or tunes. Just orchestral ambient sound like every other indie/western developed game! The graphics and aesthetics are terrible. Sprites and backgrounds are incredibly basic, while modern bloom and other lighting techniques are applied to pour excrement onto the already mediocre graphics, making the overall presentation nauseating. The environments themselves are also poorly designed and entirely unmemorable. The gameplay has the potential to be good, like the variety of weapons at your disposal. Unfortunately this game controls like Wayne's World on SNES. I'm not one to complain about short games, but I reached the ending of this in a mere 2 hours. Nothing compared to the intricately designed maps featured in the Castlevania games, which feature true exploration and puzzles. At the end of the day this game is just a shallow imitation of the Castlevania games released on the GBA/DS. Do yourself a favor and play those, and stay far away from this game.

Personally, the combination of a roguelike and a sidescroller game was a delightful combination that I didn't think could work well together. This game is naturally hard but given enough time and practice swift mastery isn't an implausibility. Needless to say the challenge of this game is what makes it so fun to begin with not to mention the inbuilt mechanic where to build your arsenal with each attempt. Overall, don't be intimidated by the difficulty of this game because failure will inevitably lead to success.

In my library filled with tight platformers, great mechanics, and even greater stories, Dead Cells falls short on nearly all of them. It does nothing great, and every negative far outweighs anything good from a game that barely even has a story.

If you only have $10 and plan to spend the rest of your time playing a repetitive, unbalanced, not-even-Metroidvania, this is the game for you.

Yes, you'll be using the wiki quite a bit, it doesn't help anyway. There are very clear build paths that you're supposed to happen upon without help in blind a blind 'playthrough.'. 

The item descriptions don't make any sense in regards to synergy or how they're supposed to work half the time.

The worst part, is that you'll be spending hours getting to the same area you were before just for 3 minutes of new content and unless you lucked your way into a nice build, you'll be spending another hour to get there. This isn't even 'Souls Like' levels of wasted time. This is padded out nonsense with 95% of your items being useless, and a completionist's hellscape.

This game has JUICE, man. And so much character! I'm not a huge fan of 2D platformers, but this game doesn't ask too too much of you in that regard so I'm alright with that. I admit that I had a bit of a bias going in because this game is a rogueLITE, and I'm a tiny bit of an elitist when it comes to roguelikes. That's a personal thing, though. The roguelite elements are fun, and similar to the likes of Hades or Binding of Isaac. Not handholdy at all. I hadn't realized that this game is a bit of a metroidvania, and am very much enjoying that part of it. 

I mentioned character. Honestly, the trailer for the game communicates the game's tone pretty well. It's set in one of the most depressing settings I've ever seen in any media, but the tone is still very lighthearted and fun. And this is the first non-rpg I've ever played where the main character flips off an NPC. (Don't worry, it's pixelated. The whole game is.) I love the references to other games, and I am in love with the sheer breadth of content.

Dead Cells is probably one of the best platformers I've ever played, everything clearly has so much love put into it by the Devs, and Motion Twin should be super proud of what they've achieved. The art direction is fantastic and colourful, the gameplay smooth and fast, and the soundtrack goes SO hard. It is quite frankly a masterpiece, and the daunting challenge of reaching the games true ending (something which I am yet to do ~150 hours in at the time of this review) doesn't become stale thanks to a masterfully executed roguelike formula. Do yourself a favour and pick up Dead Cells! Its freaking awesome.

One of the best roguelikes I've ever played. Ridiculously addictive, fast, fluid, and fun combat. I recommend everyone try this hella fun game!

I do not recommend it for its end game difficulty increase modes since it puts too much of an emphasis on playing perfectly with its ever so dwindling supply of health potions for the entire run, and getting rid of ways to restore your health after boss fights, which is made more punishing by there being a chance of getting weapons that are too weak to do the later parts of the run and thus making fights lasting longer than it should.

Despite Dead Cells's ascension modes being too difficult, even for a roguelike, I still highly recommend it to anyone who's into action games!

This game changed how I viewed a whole genre... Was always nervous to try out playing any Rogue-lite/like games because the thought of dying and losing all progress seemed like the complete opposite of what fun sounds like to me. My only experience was that I tried Binding of Isaac and thought it was okay. Then one day I was hanging out at a friend's place and she asked me to try it out, I sucked pretty bad but I liked the movement and combat. It didn't matter that I died though because it wasn't my file, so I tried a few more runs and thought it was neat that you didn't actually lose everything. Then I got home and had the urge to try it again but had to wait until I visited again. I played it a couple more times over there and each time I left I wanted to play more but didn't want to wait until I was over at their place again so I eventually bit the bullet and bought it for myself. At first I thought I wasn't gonna have as much fun since I had to start from square one, then I played it and time and progression flew by quick! This has become one of those games where I can keep going back to time and time again and start playing whenever I have nothing else to play. Basically everything about it is great from art direction to controlling your character and even the option to make it easier or harder if you want. I ended up buying all of the DLCs which I think says something for a game I was hesitant about getting in the first place. So this game has earned a special place in my heart because it showed me the amazement that this genre can be!

This game was the stepping stone that got me into the addicting genre of rogue like games. Having what feels like a sizable collection of rogue like games, I can confidently say that this is my favorite out of all of them. It's combat is engaging, and each run feels fresh with the number of unlockable number of items you can find. It is also constantly getting updated by the wonderful Motion Twin, adding new content through updates and DLCs. I'm very on the fence about this game. Once you get into it, it's really fun. It lends itself to fast-paced gameplay, zooming around tearing through enemies, which is incredibly satisfying. Improving feels rewarding, and earning your first few Boss Cells (rewards for completing a run which send you back the start to do it again, with increased difficulty) is really satisfying. The OST is also exceptional and the artstyle, though a somewhat mixed bag, really shines in a lot of the backgrounds for the different environments.

The problems - which to be honest are inherent to the game from the beginning - really start to show themselves once you hit 3/4BC as the game just becomes such a complete slog. 

There is definitely an element of mechanical skill to Dead Cells - you need to be able to react to enemies, obviously. But a large part of getting good at the game is purely knowledge. There are an absurd number of enemies, each with their own attack patterns and telegraphs. Becoming familiar with all of these is the biggest component of "gitting gud". Each biome has its own pool of enemies (some enemies show up in multiple places; others are exclusive to certain biomes), so learning a biome essentially constitutes learning how to read the enemies within it (and re-learning that pool each time new ones are added with new BCs).

Because the game never changes fundamentally between the Boss Cell levels, you're running the same biomes every time. You're therefore faced with a choice - you can just stick to the one route and minimise the amount of setbacks you'll face learning totally new enemies in addition to the BC difficulty increases (which really, is optimal, for reasons I'll get to), or you can mix it up for the sake of variety, but substantially increase the time you spend playing as you get used to dealing with new mobs. In the case of the latter, the variety is largely cancelled out by the frustration of losing what progress you'd made, since your existing mechanical skill only carries you so far against completely new enemies.

So you do the former. And this is what makes sense, as there is quite literally a best route in the game. Sewers->Prison->Sewers->Graveyard->Cavern straight up just gives you more scrolls. And you want scrolls, because the multiplicative scaling is really the best way by far to counter 5BC. Either you nuke everything, or you get nuked. And when one scroll is worth potentially hundreds of percentage more damage, of course you're going to take it.

All of this to say, grinding 5BC essentially just constitutes staring at Toxic Sewers for hours on end, especially if you're doing lots of runs to try achievements, or multiple routes/bosses. It ceases to be fun entirely.

Some other miscellaneous issues:
- The scroll system is poor. As soon as you start scaling, you're locked into a colour and two thirds of weapons become actively detrimental pickups.
- Weapons suffer the same issue as enemies. There are so many that you can either devote hundreds of hours to learning them, or turn on custom mode and engage with a handful you're comfortable with.
- The visual clutter is the worst I've ever seen. The accessibility update options mitigate this somewhat, but it's still not great. Pixel vomit everywhere.
- The game insists on having platforming sections despite the platforming being godawful. The jump feels sluggish and you snap to ledges to mantle them from miles away, removing pretty much any and all room for tight, skilful platforming. It's actually frustrating when you try to make a precise jump past something only to snap to it from halfway across the screen because the game is more interested in catering to people who have never played a platformer before.
- A lot of the "difficulty" comes from cheap enemies that wallhack you from off-screen and just very high volumes of very high-damage mobs that just get spammed more and more as the BCs go up, rather than any tests of mechanical skill, or game knowledge, which is part of what contributes to the sloggy feeling.
- The writing is painful. The game tries to have its cake and eat it too with le spooky mysterious vague lore a la Hollow Knight, but also le epic Rick and Morty taking nothing seriously jokes and banter, none of which is funny. One of the more poignant story beats (though that is a generous description) is undercut by the cringest line and le epic troll middle finger moment I've ever seen. It's like the Marvel "so that just happened!" on crack.
- The super secret ultra final twist boss is wildly underwhelming. One of the blandest, easiest final boss fights I've ever encountered. The rest of the bosses are also nothing to write home about. The game's combat shines better in biomes, at least before the grind wears you down.
- The devs milk this game to an obnoxious degree. Middling, half-hearted updates and DLCs years after launch, balance patches for a single player game - just move on lmao. All it serves to do is add bloat, which is bad for the player, because all these new weapons just take up space in your loot pool over the weapons you actually want to see, unless you're willing to sink potentially a thousand hours in learning every single weapon, but the combination of how insane an undertaking that'd be, and the existence of custom mode, makes me assume that isn't how the game is intended to be played.
- Also on the devs, they literally launched the game without an ending, and while the DLC that added it was free, the rest slotting into the main game despite being paywalled feels a little slimy.

Overall, Dead Cells is a game that seems to discourage you from engaging with it. It's designed in such a way that optimising for the smallest amount of content makes the game most bearable. And given how obnoxious it becomes anyway, maybe that's for the best. If you're content just playing this to 3BC, you'll probably have a blast, but as a full experience, I can't recommend it, especially for a comparatively high price tag (especially accounting for the DLC) as indie games go.

Great game, the builds never seem to get old and just about anything can be viable if you put enough time and thought into it. As for DLC, the devs have done a better job than any other indie game I have ever played at supporting this game and delivering quality DLC time and time again. While I haven't racked up a ton of time on this game in Steam, I've been playing [i]Dead Cells[/i] since its release on the PSN in 2018. Hundreds of hours spent; well over 500 runs on that save file.

The game is just all-around great and the amount of updates the devs have offered over the years proves that they still love this world they've made and value its fans. A lot has changed (usually for the better; ask the veteran players how Malaise used to work) but the standard gameplay has mostly remained the same because it was already strong from day one.

[i]Dead Cells[/i] can be tough, but in an accessible way. By the time you've successfully completed your first run and obtained the first (of perhaps many) Boss Cell, you will have amassed a vast inventory of tricks, tactics, weapons, abilities, and allies that got you that far and are more than capable of carrying you further. Things feeling stale? Boss Cells will up the challenge while providing something special. There are optional modes and a mountain of settings to shift around the gameplay. Free DLC ensures that there'll still be something new to discover; paid DLC is fairly priced and opens up new ways to complete runs.

Dead Cells: A Masterful Metroidvania
Dead Cells is a roguelike metroidvania that has quickly become one of my favorite games of all time. It's a perfect blend of challenging gameplay, rewarding progression, and addictive atmosphere.

The game's procedurally generated levels are always fresh and exciting, and the combat is fast-paced and brutal. There's a huge variety of weapons and abilities to experiment with, and each run feels different from the last.

I also love the game's sense of progression. As you play, you'll unlock new weapons, abilities, and items that will make you more powerful and help you reach new areas. It's incredibly satisfying to see your character grow stronger over time.

The game's atmosphere is also top-notch. The visuals are dark and atmospheric, and the soundtrack is hauntingly beautiful. It really sucks you into the world of Dead Cells.

The new Return to Castlevania DLC is a great addition to the game. It features new levels, enemies, and bosses that are inspired by the classic Castlevania games. It's a great way to relive some nostalgia, and it also adds some much-needed challenge to the game.

Overall, Dead Cells is a masterpiece. It's a must-play for fans of roguelikes, metroidvanias, or just great games in general. I highly recommend it.

Dead Cells was one of my first games where I truly exclaimed to myself, 'Damn, I'm having so much FUN!' There was a growing excitement within me as I progressed, encountering new enemies, exploring new biomes, and acquiring new weapons. Every step and jump I took was an absolute blast.

The game offers incredibly smooth and satisfying combat, accompanied by a mind-boggling array of weapons and abilities to choose from. The combinations of these elements frequently complement each other. The variety of enemy types encountered throughout the game is refreshingly diverse as you navigate through each level. The artwork, animations, and soundtracks are all fantastic, amplifying the overall experience a hundredfold. What I enjoy the most in this game are the boss fights. Game have some incredible boss fights and the satisfaction of defeating a boss never gets old.

I highly recommend this game, and I hope you'll enjoy it as much as I do. :)

Dead Cells is a high speed platformer action game that tries to mash the roguelite and metroidvania genres together. Unfortunately I didn't find the result anything special.

The art is really pretty with high quality animation and detailed pixel art backgrounds, while gameplay is designed to be fast paced with branching paths that take you towards different areas each with their own enemies and bosses to face against. Each step of the way you get access to random upgrades, unlock permanent improvements, and there's a variety of game modifiers. Sadly this game jumps on the 'souls like' train so you know what that means.

Souls-likes always suffer the same problem - every enemy becomes a knowledge-gate instead of a skill-check. There's more to be learned from souls games than just ramping up the volatility but few designers pick up on that and gamers foam at the mouth to be whipping boys for this style of arbitrarily hard gameplay. The result is you either waste weeks learning each knowledge gate or you put the game down and get meme'd on by everyone suffering from sunk cost fallacy - either way there are no true winners.

Overall dead cells feels like it has the potential to be a pretty solid game but squanders it. I can't see the combat design as anything other than lazy and while it tries to make up for it with fast gameplay to get you back in the action this just results in an incredibly repetitive experience without the substance to make investing in it worthwhile.

The writing is absolutely charming and it's filled to bursting with references both indirect and direct, I love playing as Jacket from the Hotline Miami series to bash in Castlevania enemies.

The soundtrack fucks, The gameplay fucks, the Art fucks.

The game is really fun and the synergy between all the equipment you can get is fantastic, but I have two complaints about the game. The fist is the final boss. You're placed in a very small arena and the boss has very quick attacks, which can kill you in two hits. I used the training area to practice against this boss, but I still couldn't get it down. I think this boss battle difficulty is too high, even on custom game mode. The second complaint is how long it takes to unlock things. The game takes a lot of grinding, even for costumes. I enjoyed my time and I got my money's worth, but these two issues caused me to stop playing.

A game which I keep find myself coming back to again and again. One of the most satisfying game loops in the Roguelike genre, and with a dev team that actively listens to player feedback and pumps out quality updates. Been playing since Early Access, and I always point to this game as one of the success stories of Early Access done right. They even include some weapons and skins from other indie games, such as Risk of Rain, Hyperlight Drifter, Blasphemous, Hotline Miami, etc. to keep things spicy at no extra cost

Can hop in and hop out for a few runs at a time, get frustrated at getting ganked by a bunch of enemies and take a break, then hop right back on again the next day. An utterly satisfying experience, if you are willing to tackle the challenge. Assist mode makes the game more accessible (have turned on infinite deaths now and then to guarantee getting some unlocks here and there), but being able to go toe-to-toe with the base game and its mechanics is such a rewarding experience. Easily one of my most played games in my library, by a pretty wide margin.
