Dead Cells is an adrenaline-pumping and addictive action-platformer that will keep you hooked for hours on end. With its dynamic combat, procedurally generated levels, and stunning pixel art, this game offers an unforgettable experience that leaves you craving more.

[b]Graphics:[/b]
The pixel art in Dead Cells is a visual treat. Each environment is meticulously crafted, from hauntingly beautiful dungeons to eerie forests and treacherous castles. The attention to detail and smooth animations add depth to the game's world, making every moment visually engaging. The blend of dark and vibrant colors sets the perfect mood for the game's challenging and atmospheric gameplay.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
Dead Cells' gameplay is where it truly shines. The fast-paced combat is a joy to master, offering a satisfying mix of sword-slashing, arrow-shooting, and spell-casting. The game's "Roguevania" approach, combining rogue-like elements with the exploration of a metroidvania, creates a compelling and ever-changing experience. Each run feels fresh, as the levels, enemies, and loot are procedurally generated, keeping you on your toes and encouraging experimentation with different playstyles.

[b]Audio:[/b]
The audio design in Dead Cells complements the gameplay perfectly. The ominous soundtrack sets the mood for the intense battles and exploration, while the sound effects provide visceral feedback to your actions. The clashing of weapons, the creaking of doors, and the eerie echoes of the environment immerse you in the game's dangerous world, adding to the adrenaline rush of combat.

[b]Story:[/b]
While not heavily story-driven, Dead Cells offers subtle hints of lore that pique your curiosity as you progress. The game's mysterious narrative and enigmatic characters encourage you to piece together the game's world and history bit by bit. It's a testament to the game's design that even without a prominent plotline, players find themselves drawn deeper into the game's secrets.

[b]Difficulty:[/b]
Dead Cells strikes a satisfying balance between accessibility and challenge. The initial stages provide a smooth learning curve, allowing new players to get accustomed to the mechanics and enemies. However, as you progress, the difficulty ramps up significantly, demanding quick reflexes and strategic decision-making. Each death feels like a learning opportunity, motivating you to return and improve your skills.

[b]Grind:[/b]
The grind in Dead Cells is thoughtfully balanced. While gathering cells and blueprints to unlock new weapons and abilities requires some effort, it never feels like an overwhelming grind. The diverse and rewarding upgrades make the progression feel worthwhile, encouraging players to explore different paths and strategies.

[b]Game Time:[/b]
With its replayable nature and ever-changing levels, Dead Cells offers a significant amount of gameplay. Depending on your skill level and desire to uncover all its secrets, you can easily spend tens to hundreds of hours immersed in the game's challenging and addictive world.

[b]Price:[/b]
Dead Cells' price is well worth the experience it offers. The depth, variety, and replay value justify the cost, making it a standout title in its genre.

Dead Cells is a triumph of game design that sets a new standard for action-platformers. Its addictive gameplay, stunning pixel art, and engaging audio create a seamless and immersive experience. If you're a fan of challenging and rewarding games, Dead Cells is an essential addition to your gaming library.

The combat is shallow but fun and satisfying enough, the main character is animated really well which makes the really poor quality choppy animations of the enemies and NPCs stick out like a sore thumb, the base game really doesn't have a whole lot of content, but my main issue is really how DLC is implemented.  They leave in all the doors to DLC content and the ways you get to them, so you think you've found some cool secret level, but then the game tells you to go fuck yourself and give them your money when this content really should've been in the base game.  It feels like they cut the game in half and then put a price tag on the parts of the game they took out, because it doesn't really have much content without the DLC.  I don't know if said DLC is any good, and I probably never will, because I don't feel like paying almost double the price of the very underwhelming base game just to get something that resembles a complete product.  5/10

Purchased mid 2023 and I think I'm going to refund it.

I wasn't gripped by the core gameplay loop, and at first I wondered why. This game seemed to have made some waves in the roguelite space. It definitely seemed popular, it has all this DLC released well after it's launch. Surely it must be good?

But I don't think this game really shapes up to it's modern competitors. Maybe in 2018 the combat was visceral and fast, but we have games like Hades now. Maybe back then the metroidvania elements were alot more fresh, but we've had both Rogue Legacy games now and it's successor delivers so much better on that feel.
The visuals are unique, gave me little nostalgias about the weird 3d graphics of some gameboy advance games. But whilst a unique and interesting art style is no less an outstanding achievement - it's practically a given for any major release in this genre, let alone the main vehicle that indie games use to stand out.

I guess in the year of our lord 2023, I'm alot more interested in rogues with more unique gameplay experiences like Gunfire: Reborn or Domekeeper. Funny game where I keep restarting, move left and right and hit man with funny basic 3 hit combos isn't as fresh today and have much fiercer competition.

If you're interested in Dead Cells, check out any of the other games I just mentioned. I'd also like to point to Risk of Rain 2 and Enter the Gungeon.

TLDR: Not a bad game, there's just better nowadays.

This game is an absolute blast! It's a fast-paced, action-packed experience that keeps you hooked from the start. The pixel art style is gorgeous, and the controls are intuitive and easy to learn. The procedurally generated levels ensure each run feels fresh and exciting. With a wide variety of weapons and abilities to discover, the gameplay remains engaging and constantly evolving. Dead Cells strikes a perfect balance between difficulty and fun, making every victory feel earned. I can't get enough of it and highly recommend it to anyone who loves action-packed games.

When I was comparing two amulets to see which one had more DPS, I asked myself: why do I keep doing this to myself? Why do I keep buying these number-go-up dopamine meat grinders?

I feel like I've become increasingly tired of all this kind of games. It seems like there's only one way to use procedurally generated content in videogames and every studio has to Do That Thing now or they can't market their indie game (or even some AA / AAA) to the masses.

Or maybe these games are a metaphor, and I'm stuck in a loop of buying the same game but with small changes, and quitting over and over again.

Some day I may be free of the loop.

[h1]Live. Die. Repeat.[/h1]

That’s Dead Cells core concept in three little words. This Castlevania-inspired roguelike charges you with journeying through an ever-changing castle, surviving using only your wits, learned skills and a variety of different weapons and gadgets.

Along the way, you collect Cells. These are gathered by wiping out enemies or liberating them from secret areas in the game world. They can be used to pay for upgrades that persist forever: perhaps there is a special weapon that you want to unlock as a piece of loot in game, or the ability to heal yourself twice with a health potion, or even three times.

Eventually, you’ll die. There are no checkpoints and you will be unceremoniously dumped back into the starting area, ready to try again. While you lose your money and Cells, your upgrades will persist and you get to try again.

Certain upgrades can let you keep hold of a chunk of your cash, but it’s losing the Cells that really hurts: these can only be spent on the progression-enabling upgrades at the end of each level, so several times during play you could find yourself losing 30 or even 50 Cells after a death. It’s not an exaggeration to say that losing a significant chunk of these is agonising, and provides a strong impetus to perform better next time.

This loop of performance and self-improvement is the chewy meat that holds Dead Cells together, and it’s satisfying enough to carry the entire game on its back. While the levels are procedurally generated, they obey specific rules and by learning them you can start to see the patterns in the generation and use them to your advantage.

To escape from the castle ramparts you need to venture downwards, the mushroom doctor’s room has a hidden passage, and digging into the bottom of the well will often yield goodies. There isn’t always a well, or the mushroom doctor’s room, and they may look different each time, but learning these little bits of information will help you make an impact each time these opportunities rear their head.

This is true of the enemies too. It’s important to learn each adversaries’ unique attack patterns and behaviours if you want to survive. There’s a remarkable amount of variety throughout the game’s roster of enemies, whether it’s angular scorpions firing venom, mages firing projectiles through walls or even teleporting swordsmen that, after they’ve caught your scent, never stop chasing you.

All of these appear in the first few areas of Dead Cells before you encounter the first major boss, and all of them are immediately challenging until you learn how they work.

You’ll also get to grips with the game’s remarkable arsenal. The weapons — roughly divided into melee, ranged and shields — and power-ups that you can get your hands on are interesting and drop at random, with similarly random traits and rarities.

A gold quality weapon, gold being the highest rarity item, will often come stuffed full of invaluable traits to help you wipe out enemies. Get a couple of these and your run is somewhat charmed, a series of weird particle effects and damage over time attacks chipping away at the swirling mass of enemies around you.

Some of the items feel overpowered, and I initially thought the Ice Bow in the game would redefine any run. Later, I found success with a Hokuto’s Bow: this wondrous thing massively increases the damage that an enemy takes.

Then I got a gold rarity shield that wouldn’t allow me to parry but meant that I took the bare minimum of damage from attacks and reflected 300 percent of any damage blocked while taking a tiny chip of my health. Suddenly, anything I’d marked that attacked me instantly exploded, and two of the games big bosses also fell afoul of it, taking big chunks of damage every time they tried to hurt me.

It’s the combat in the game that keeps me coming back. No other game has quite managed to capture the joy of combat like this. Whether you’re clutching a bow and sword, or hiding away behind a shield and tossing throwing knives, the kinetic energy of the combat makes the unforgiving nature of the game feel like a strength, not a weakness. After learning how the enemies tick, tearing through them is a joy.

The sound and visuals are excellent too. The movement and attacks look nice but it’s the smaller details that really make it; ride an elevator and sparks come off the walls and chain, fire spreads across the floor, glowing blue if it touches off some oil left on the ground. Get to low health and you’ll leak blood.

There is real care and attention that’s been given, and it’s impossible not to notice. The different levels all have their own distinctive look, and the technical performance is flawless, so even when everyone on the screen is being torn apart, everything looks good and the framerate is stable.

What problems Dead Cells does have is in its progression system. Broadly, while you can succeed at the game with just a couple of the ability-granting runes, getting to many areas requires you to pick up items that will allow you to wall-jump or smash through weak floors below you.

Getting these is poorly signposted, and as these persistent upgrades are key to exploring some of the weirder areas in the game, it is frustrating to bash your head against it repeatedly until you work out where you’re supposed to go, as you fight your way through levels again and again.

This is a shame because the game really does thrive when you explore, with amusing writing and some excellent environmental storytelling. Unfortunately, more casual players will probably be turned away by the sheer amount of work needed to get the final two skill runes, and writing the game off too early because of that.

Coming into the crowded Metroidvania genre was a bold move, but one that seems to have paid off as Dead Cells has delivered the best example of the genre in years. The game is deep and rewards exploration, with exceptional combat and so much content it’s honestly a little intimidating.

Fast paced, non-stop frantic action with tight controls and a well balanced difficulty curve.

Game allows you to go at your own pace and encourages experimentation by slowly unlocking new starting weapons and skills. You can add modifiers to make the game easier or harder from the outset, and are rewarded for taking more on more difficult biomes on the way to the first boss.

The game is beautiful, sound design perfectly telegraphs enemy move sets without being intrusive, and what lore exists is drip fed through random hidden rooms. Easter eggs by the truckload, and you can use weapons and meet NPCs from other games.

Dead Cells is a captivating fusion of the rogue-like and metroidvania genres, boasting atmospheric pixel art and adrenaline-pumping combat mechanics. The game's vast array of weapons and abilities provide strategic depth, and its intriguing, unfolding story, alongside its unique blend of procedural and hand-crafted world-building, creates a rewarding and immersive experience. With continuous updates expanding the game's content, Dead Cells stands as a shining testament to indie gaming's potential, delivering a challenging yet satisfying journey that rivals big-budget AAA titles.

Title: A Brilliant Homage to Classic Metroidvania - Dead Cells: Return to Castlevania

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐½

Dead Cells: Return to Castlevania is a masterful PC game that pays homage to the beloved Castlevania series while delivering its own unique and exhilarating experience. With its seamless blend of fast-paced action, Metroidvania exploration, and addictive roguelike elements, Dead Cells: Return to Castlevania is a must-play for fans of the genre.

One of the standout features of Dead Cells: Return to Castlevania is its fluid and satisfying combat. The game seamlessly combines melee and ranged combat, providing players with a wide array of weapons and abilities to unleash upon their enemies. The combat mechanics are precise and responsive, creating a thrilling and rewarding experience as you navigate through hordes of challenging foes. The variety of enemy types and boss battles keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging, requiring strategic thinking and precise timing to succeed.

The Metroidvania exploration in Dead Cells: Return to Castlevania is superbly executed. The game offers a sprawling interconnected world filled with secrets, hidden passages, and branching paths. As you progress, you unlock new abilities and upgrades that grant access to previously inaccessible areas, rewarding exploration and encouraging backtracking. The level design is intricate and well-crafted, offering a sense of discovery and accomplishment as you unravel the mysteries of the castle.

The roguelike elements in Dead Cells: Return to Castlevania add a layer of challenge and replayability. Each run presents a unique combination of randomly generated levels, enemies, and power-ups, ensuring that no two playthroughs are the same. The permadeath mechanic adds tension and risk-reward gameplay, pushing players to make strategic decisions and adapt to ever-changing circumstances. The sense of progression comes from unlocking permanent upgrades and new weapons that carry over between runs, offering a sense of growth and accomplishment.

The visual and audio design in Dead Cells: Return to Castlevania is exceptional. The pixel art graphics are beautifully crafted, paying homage to the classic Castlevania games while adding modern flair. The animations are smooth and detailed, adding weight and impact to the combat. The atmospheric soundtrack perfectly complements the dark and gothic ambiance of the game, immersing players in its haunting world.

While Dead Cells: Return to Castlevania offers a fantastic gameplay experience, some players may find the difficulty level challenging. The game can be punishing at times, requiring precise timing and quick reflexes. However, for fans of challenging games, this adds to the satisfaction of overcoming obstacles and mastering the gameplay mechanics.

In conclusion, Dead Cells: Return to Castlevania is an outstanding PC game that successfully captures the essence of classic Metroidvania gameplay while adding its own unique twist. With its fluid combat, captivating exploration, and addictive roguelike elements, it offers a thrilling and rewarding experience from start to finish. The homage to the Castlevania series and the attention to detail in its design make it a must-play for fans of the genre. Prepare to delve into the darkness and rediscover the magic of Castlevania in Dead Cells: Return to Castlevania.

I cannot recommend this game enough. This game is easily the best game since Symphony of the Night. Fantastic fast paced action in a roguelike is great. This game has a staggering amount of unlockables, which is something that many games have been missing. Unlockable weapons, outfits, mutations. 21 hours in and I haven't even scathed the surface of this game. While a big game overall with massive replayablility, it is not hard to pick up and play. The game has added multiple DLCs which add a more of what makes the game great. Even has a streamer mode which pulls the chat into the roles of Captain Chicken (who allows you to heal, when they want), and even can add abilities to the Bosses, as well as a voting feature to make every level harder or slightly easier. Recommend buying this game when on sale or at full price if you enjoy rougelike games or Castlevania.

I beat this game and there is very little sense of accomplishment on really any achievement. By the time i finished it I was more relieved that this game was over rather than sad its come to an end. Nothing really matters and its mostly RNG for a good set of items that lets allows the player to shred the levels no problem. Its not really a great game, however,  it will take time which some players seek. Its nice that the graphics are very old school so any PC can play it. There are a few bright points however most the time after the player takes damage they feel cheated rather than shown that they played incorrectly. Very inconsistent hitboxes, enemies not responding to players position consistently, parry symbol not matching timing of parry, alot of cltter on the screen which most the time makes the player have no idea what hit them. There are better games on the market right now and I cant recommend this game. Most likely any person who reads this and disagrees will just say "Skill Issue" but like I said I beat this game BC5 100% I dont want to give away any spoilers multiple times. 

I felt more frustration during my play through than I did any other emotion. Clearly I am in the minority but just be weary of this games groupthink culture.

Honestly, Dead Cells is a good game. But not for me. And I think I have to give credit to Dead Cells because it has shown to me that I don't like rougelikes, or rougelites. Or whatever the hell is a rougevania, which is possibly the worst thing I've ever heard. This game is not similar to a metroidvania at all since all progression is lost upon death except for weapon and skill unlocks. And progression with better stats and new abilities through a persistent map is a core concept of a metroidvania so I highly disagree. This is not a metroidvania. But sure pop off I guess. 

I'm getting sidetracked by my hatred for genre names. 

Dead cells is a fun game. But one I could only tolerate for up until beating the first boss, at least on pc. On the switch I put about 20 hours into the game and had a fun time but stopped. The reason why? Simply put: with rougelite games there tends to be such a fixture on tons of content to unlock and meta progression that there never feels like there's a level of rewarding progress for me the player. It's always progress towards making the next "run" potentially better. I know most of my issues with the game could (and probably should) be chalked up to my lack of skill in these types of games. But it's just something I don't vibe with. I never feel rewarded for playing. I always feel punished for trying to get farther and farther in these kind of games, by constantly hitting a wall of sorts and being thrown back to the start of the game with nothing except the "unlocks" I got to maybe, randomly, help me *this* time. So what feels like something that would take me around 2-5 hours in a non-rougelike game, feels like it's going to take me 20+ hours to beat in a game like Dead Cells, purely because of this "meta" progression and luck. And I do not have the patience to put something like 200+ hours to beat a game like this.

I know this isn't just a problem in Dead Cells but other rougelite games as well. Hell, I am even fully aware that this meta progression is the exact reason some people really enjoy these types of games. But for me it takes me right out of the game.

Obviously most people really enjoy this game. It has like a 97% overwhelmingly positive rating here on steam with over 100,000 reviews. That's incredibly impressive, though more of just a stat to show how well this game has reached it's target audience. So I'm not looking to change views on this game at all.

But I still have to give credit to Dead Cells, because it has helped me confirm that even if a game is popular, doesn't mean it's a perfect match for everyone. I think this is it for rougelikes for me in general. I think in the future I'm just going to avoid any game that mentions rougelike from here on out.

Dead Cells is one of the very best indie games I have ever played. As an action rougelike-metriodvania, developer Motion Twin knocked it out of the park. Every biome / area the player explores is vast with tons of enemies, secrets, goodies to find. As in the name, the rouge like nature means every run or attempt feels different. I can play through the same biome 20 times in a row, and each run will never feel like the last. The combos is crisp and fluid. Attacking, jumping, parrying, etc, every control the player can use is fully based on skill. When you get a kill that's 100% on you, but the same goes for death. This game does not cheat you, when you die, its 100% YOUR fault. There are so many weapons and skills to unlock, so many areas to uncover, and although this game was release almost 5 years ago, they are still updating it with more content. The cell shaded graphics are terrific, and the music goes hard in every single level. Not much to criticize here except maybe the lack of a multi-player mode. I feel like this game have functioned well with a 2-4 player option. 

9.4/10

Welcome back to my 40+ hour review corner. Today's game of choice is Dead Cells.

When I first got it I thought it'd be simple and fun, how wrong I was, the game BROKE me when doing the 100% grind for all achievements. But it was so rewarding when I saw that golden badge appear. Definitely the toughest achievement was running through all levels with a cursed sword against all bosses. Now let's get to the core aspects of the game!

OST: 8/10, the songs are pretty good, they do support the theme of a medieval like island.
Gameplay: 10/10, The gameplay is super unique no matter what path you take, you'll always end up in the same place or another.
Weaponry: 10/10, Every weapon has an insanely unique play style, attack pattern, and attacks, so no matter the run you'll always be trying something different to reach the Throne.
Bosses: 9/10, The bosses are indeed interesting, learning their attack patterns are a pain but worth it when you do the cursed sword run for those delicious achievements. 
Zones: 10/10, All the zones you see in the game follow a specific theme, like the sewers or dilapidated obituary, whatever it's called, you can see the world just flow with life and death, as you run through the zones!

The game was indeed fun to play, especially trying to get all achievements. You'll definitely need to use some forms of tactical prowess to get through all the achievements for that golden medal. Especially the more annoying ones, that require a specific rarity or loot drop. 

Final Rating: 9/10, the game was good. Just still feeling the pain of achievements after beating it all.

I reviewed this game a while ago after I'd clocked 100 hours on it. After more than doubling that time, I still know I have many, many more to come.

Ever since I started playing this game as it was in early access, it's been my favorite game of all time. I've played quite a few games in quite a variety of genres, and while there are some that come within a swinging distance, nothing has ever reached the heights of how amazing this one feels to play for me. The movement, the mechanics, the replayability and constant progression, the story and how it's conveyed, the atmosphere, the soundtrack, and all of the subtle touches that the game never explicitly points out to you (such as auto-turning you around if you initiate an attack while facing away from an enemy) culminate into the most reliably enjoyable experience I have ever had with any piece of media.

I don't know how reliable of a source I am, I'm hardly somebody to look to if you're searching for any kind of objective take. Many things I've heard other people criticize about this game are also things I have noticed, but appreciate about this game. It is one of the most punishing things I've ever come across -- with how much lenience and the insane variety they provide the player with, the game has to be as unforgiving as possible within the bounds of the rules it sets -- but I have never had as much fun in the process of butting my head against a wall as I have with this game, and no other gaming accomplishment has reached the satisfaction of finally overcoming something that has thrown me in the dirt time and time again. It's also extremely refreshing to see a development studio as passionate as the ones behind this.

Tl;dr, easily my personal favorite video game, without a question. I do feel like a lot of it is something I specifically am predisposed to adoring, but I will always recommend this game. Unless you don't find fun in experiences that cause frustration at times, because this game will piss you off.

Dead Cells is advertised to have 10-30 hours of playtime. But with 6 difficulties in total, from normal to up to five boss cells, and countless items to be experimented with, it can easily be more than that. At the time of writing, I've played for 100 hours (probably minus the several hours I accidentally left the game on), and I've only beaten the first 3 difficulties. Each difficulty has unique attributes that have you coming back for more every time. Depending on how much you want to commit to this game, you could easily get 300+ hours out of it. And it's for sure still worth it even if you only plan on beating the first difficulty. Give the game a shot, you'll have a blast.

Also, the DLCs are awesome, highly recommend you buy them as well.

This game just fun not just for the combat system, but for the way it encourages players to slowly get better and improve their tactics over time. Running through what seems like an endless dungeon starts a new player in a place of exploration, awe, and discovery. As the game is learned, and the mechanics mastered, you realize how much more there is to explore and improve. There is so much strategy comes into play choosing what path to travel down, and what weapon set you go with. The game is fast, fluid, and the sense of danger and adrenaline that comes from taking risks makes this an amazingly repayable game. Then as you reach what seems to be the end of the game, you realize there is so much more to replay, so much more to unlock; and that the difficulty, right as you master it, will throw in another boss cell and more difficult mode.

Dead Cells is an extremely fun rogue-lite game that gets progressively more difficult as you go on. The game allows for a wide range of play styles from tactical, calculated play to DPS monsters. The high difficulty makes the game extremely rewarding for those willing to see it through to the end. Overall, the game is one of the best I have ever played.

I remember first picking up this game on my mobile phone and sunk tons of hours playing it.  Now I got the game here on Steam and have sunken even more hours, finally acquiring all of the achievements as of update 34.

Dead Cells is a very fun game that can be enjoyed by both casual and hardcore players. The game provides a wide variety of weapons and powerups to experiment that makes each run different and unique. There are also a lot of easter eggs and other video game references that are funny and cool. I also like the fact that the developers still provides consistent updates and new content / dlc since the release of the game.

Dead Cells deserves all the priase and positive reviews It has. I enjoyed playing this game as the combat is very fun, challenging, and satisfying. I highly recommend this to anyone that enjoys metroidvania and/or rouge-lite games.

Dead Cells is one of the most fun and addicting rogue-lite games I've ever played. I remember when I first picked up the game in 2020 on my XBOX One, I have not put it down since. Not only is this game beautiful design wise, it also has a kick ass ost that really captures the overall aesthetic of the game and lore. Each level has it's own theme, color scheme, and soundtrack making each run unique depending on what route you take. There are a plethora of weapons, upgrades, and secrets to unlock to help you take on the vast amount of horrifically awesome creatures each level offers. This game immerses you in a medieval-ish environment with mechanics that make you feel like a total bad ass while playing. The combination of pixel gore, gruesome monsters, and humor is very refreshing and well done. If you love unique indie games like Hollow Knight or Katana Zero, I absolutely recommend Dead Cells. Dead Cells overall is a game that offers so much more than you initially expect and with all the secrets and lore it has to offer, you will never get bored of it.

So, I have played this game for days now and I love it. The gameplay is just so much fun. You can have weapons that do over 30K damage per second at the end of a run, or you die trying to get to the next level because you picked up a curse and overestimated yourself. The game is basically die and die again till you achieve something, and then you die again. And also, the soundtrack is just gorgeous, I origanally bought it because of the Castlevania DLC but the whole game is just amazing. The variety of weapons and playstyles you can have is also a thing to point out. You can have bows, Swords, shields and so much more. And as you progress through the game it gets better and better because you unlock more of the weapons, the mutations and the outfits for your playercharacter. Then there are those little secrets like the Starfury from Terraria or the Pure Nail from Hollow Knight for example. You even get those weapons in little areas from the games, like the bench in Hollow Knight. Overall I would say, this game is absolutely worth the try. But the game really is unforgiving at some times. If you can get along with that, you should defintely play it.

The smoothness of the animations and controls is what is selling me hard on this game. The content can get very confusing, and how to "progress" and find cool hidden levels without a guide is difficult. The sheer amount of unlockables and content, however is staggering. The game is classic rogue lite with it seeming impossible at some points until you have that one run and you sweep the game. I'd say if you love Celeste, Binding of Isaac or gungeon, buy it asap but if not then wait for the sale and then DEFINITELY grab it WITH ITS DLC.

I'll start with saying i DO recommend this game for people who really enjoy roguelikes. it's very addictive and the combat is satisfying as hell tbh, with plenty of variety in play styles.

if you're not Super into roguelikes there's a chance that addictiveness will be good enough for you, and i think that might actually be where a lot of the positive reviews are coming from.

otherwise, i really can't recommend this game. the gameplay feels great right up until you take damage, then everything becomes clunky as hell, including stun-locking you to death for messing up a single dodge or parry. i'm sure a lot of people would say "just don't get hit lmao" or suggest that's the core of the game; everyone's supposed to be a glass cannon. except there's tons of items and passives that revolve around actively taking damage, mitigating it, and recovering, so no, that's just an oversight at best, poor design at worst.

after a while it starts to feel like the game was designed around non-boss levels specifically and bosses were an afterthought. any enemy that you can't one-shot or kill before it can act tends to feel half-thought-out and bosses are just those kinds of enemies but with more health.

according to another review on here at least, the devs have admitted (bragged) that one of the dlcs is so difficult that most people would consider it unfair, and specifically that kind of mentality has become a rampant problem with developers of difficult games. they seem to get the idea that "unfair" and "difficult" are perfect synonyms, or at the very least they think "so long as the game is hard, our job is done, no further thought required." imagine a man puts a gun to your head and says "juggle or i'll kill you" then he ties your hands behind your back. yeah i'd say that's pretty hard, mission accomplished.

then there's the fact that the game's true ending is tied to the highest difficulty, that is; tied to extreme masochism.

now that i've made some attempt at fair criticism, i hope you'll forgive me for a more emotional comment. this game doesn't even come close to earning it's overwhelmingly positive review status and the boss fights feel like sudden-onset diarrhea.

Don't understand who I'm referencing? Awww, GET SMART! Get Smart... remember that T.V. show from like 50 years ago? I watched it on Nick-At-Nite like 25 years ago when I was a kid, and it was super old to me back then!

In those days, sometimes you'd have to leave a game on all night before continuing it to beat it. Sometimes, because there were no saves. And also sometimes? Where does the time go? See-- this is why you don't play games like this. Cause then you get existential about time and worth and crap. And then you post a negative review no one will ever read on Steam for a game that everyone already likes anyway.

It's fun for a single run, but overall this gets stale incredibly fast. The enemies are downright pathetic in design choices. They're all monotonous and boring. The bosses too. Despite being 1:1 enemies, they seem to have about 3 attacks each. This gets boring spamming the same pattern over and over. Honestly, you end up impatient just waiting for the healthbars to trickle down. There's no cool effects by combining mechanics. Hades did this better, where you could combine effects to create some truly menacing builds. In this? It's stack bleed or crit damage for DPS. There's only three useful mutations, and they're so useful there's no reason to pick anything else. Parrying is worthless and unfeasable for the later runs, when everything starts to spam bombs for some reason.

It's fast-paced and actively rewards playing as such, however, everything is very much only meant to be seen as a blur.

Such a playstyle lacks depth.

Dead Cells is a phenomenal game that effortlessly blends fast-paced action, challenging gameplay, and a mesmerizing world. Developed by Motion Twin, this roguelike metroidvania is a true masterpiece that kept me hooked from start to finish. With its innovative mechanics, stunning visuals, and addictive gameplay loop, Dead Cells has become a benchmark for the genre.

One of the standout features of Dead Cells is its gameplay, which strikes a perfect balance between precision and fluidity. Controlling the agile protagonist feels incredibly responsive, and the combat mechanics are satisfyingly weighty. The wide array of weapons and abilities at your disposal ensures that every encounter feels fresh and engaging. Whether it's slicing through enemies with a lightning-fast sword or decimating them with explosive traps, Dead Cells offers an immense amount of versatility and playstyle customization.

What sets Dead Cells apart from other games is its roguelike elements. Each run through the game is procedurally generated, meaning you'll never experience the same layout twice. This adds an element of surprise and strategic thinking as you adapt to the ever-changing environments and enemy placements. The exhilarating rush of progressing through each level while managing your resources and health creates an addictive cycle of risk and reward.

Furthermore, the game's metroidvania-inspired design rewards exploration. Unlocking new areas and discovering hidden secrets provides a sense of accomplishment and fuels your desire to delve deeper into the sprawling world. The level design is meticulously crafted, with interconnected paths and shortcuts that cleverly loop back to previous areas, encouraging you to revisit them armed with new abilities.

Visually, Dead Cells is a feast for the eyes. The beautifully animated pixel art style is stunningly detailed, and the atmospheric lighting brings the hauntingly atmospheric world to life. From the grim dungeons to the eerie forests, each environment exudes a distinct ambiance that perfectly complements the gameplay.

The audio design is equally remarkable, with a haunting soundtrack that sets the tone for your perilous journey. The sound effects, from the clash of swords to the groans of defeated enemies, are crisp and satisfying, further immersing you in the game's dark and foreboding atmosphere.

In terms of replay value, Dead Cells is unparalleled. With a vast array of weapons, power-ups, and upgrades to unlock, the game constantly encourages experimentation and replayability. Each playthrough feels unique, as you adapt your strategy based on the randomly generated elements. The inclusion of various difficulty levels and unlockable modifiers ensures that even the most experienced players will find new challenges to conquer.

Dead Cells is a triumph in game design, offering a near-flawless experience. Its tight controls, addictive gameplay loop, and breathtaking visuals combine to create an unforgettable journey. Whether you're a fan of roguelikes, metroidvanias, or simply enjoy challenging and rewarding experiences, Dead Cells deserves a spot in your gaming library. It's an absolute must-play and a shining example of how to create a five-star gaming experience.

Dead Cells, an exhilarating action-platformer developed by Motion Twin, has transformed my gaming skills and provided an immersive experience that keeps me coming back for more. Its challenging gameplay and my repeated purchases across multiple devices have made it a standout title in my gaming library.

One aspect that sets Dead Cells apart is its ability to teach resilience through repeated deaths. In the game, dying is not just a setback but an opportunity for growth. Each failure becomes a lesson, pushing me to analyze my strategies, adapt my playstyle, and uncover new paths to success. This iterative process of trial and error has honed my reflexes, sharpened my decision-making abilities, and fostered a sense of determination that translates beyond the game itself.

The game's difficulty curve strikes a perfect balance, ensuring that every encounter demands precision and skill while avoiding frustratingly insurmountable challenges. Dead Cells keeps me engaged with its smooth controls, rewarding combat mechanics, and procedurally generated levels that guarantee fresh experiences with each playthrough. Overcoming seemingly impossible odds and emerging victorious instills a genuine sense of accomplishment that few other games can provide.

Moreover, my multiple purchases of Dead Cells across various devices have amplified my enjoyment of the game. The seamless transition between platforms allows me to delve into its addictive gameplay whether I'm at home, on the go, or simply seeking a change of scenery. Whether I'm slashing through hordes of enemies on my gaming console or exploring its intricate world during a commute on my mobile device, Dead Cells never fails to captivate me with its responsive controls and captivating visuals.

In summary, Dead Cells has not only elevated my gaming skills but has also taught me valuable life lessons about resilience and perseverance. Its challenging yet fair gameplay, combined with the joy of playing across multiple devices, has created a gaming experience that is truly exceptional. If you seek a game that will test your abilities, foster personal growth, and provide endless entertainment, Dead Cells is an absolute must-have in your collection.

Fast pace, hard yet satisfying

I'm enjoying the game so far because it's definitely faster paced than many rogue-lites. The metroid-vania style gameplay is easy to pick up and fairly simple to improve at. Other highlights include: The weapons are fun and the enemies all are clearly defined but , albeit, sometimes repetitive, although that's ok because the combat is very hack'n'slash in nature. The progression system for unlocking new weapons and abilities is pretty good, as well as the difficulty and enemy progression as you get deeper into runs.
      My biggest (and probably only) gripe with the game is that all of the DLC other than the free "Rise of The Giant" DLC is pretty uncreatively implemented. When you get to a door that takes you to a new biome, there's a label above it that tells you what biome it will take you to. The DLC doors look exactly the same as the rest, no locks or gates preventing access, leading players to assume they've found a new biome that's ready to be explored. However, instead of entering the door, a popup appears, saying, "You need [insert DLC here] to access this area." preventing the player from entering until said DLC is installed. I mean, from a marketing standpoint, it's genius because it compels players to buy the DLC, but from a game play standpoint, it's just kind of annoying for the the player to be presented with a new area to explore, only to be blue-balled by a pop-up. 
       Other than that, it's a great game with plenty of secrets, cross-overs, references, and lore. I highly recommend buying this game if you like rogue-lites, and I probably will end up playing at least some of the DLC. I've spent way to long on this review now, and I thank you for reading to the end.

Title: A Reflection on the Unseen

Review:
In a vast sea of information, our voices often go unheard. Yet, I find solace in expressing my thoughts freely, unaffected by external expectations.

This review delves into the essence of my experience, knowing it may never reach its intended audience. In the digital realm, my efforts seem futile, but this reflection is not about despair. It reminds us to embrace the intrinsic value of expression, rather than seeking validation.

The absence of readers liberates this review, allowing open exploration without conformity. It's a cathartic release of unburdened ideas, devoid of external scrutiny.

Consider the irony as you stumble upon this digital artifact, reflecting on the countless unexplored creations in the abyss. Let us appreciate the act of creation for its own sake, as attention becomes scarce.

This review is a testament to the beauty of expression, even in invisibility. Whether read or not, it serves its purpose—a symbol of authenticity, creative freedom, and human resilience.

Rating: Unrated
Review intended for personal reflection and contemplation only.

Bought this game 5-6 months ago at ~40% discount. Trying to beat 2BC at the time of writing of this review. Please note some aspects are opinion-based so please don't beat me with sticks in the comments.

Reasons why I recommend:
- Difficulty  
- Should run on almost any PC given the graphics quality 
- In-game music is ear candy and blends well with the environment of each biome
- Customizable difficulty using BC (boss cells), which are earned upon further progression in the game 
- Wide variety of weapons and skills to choose from
- Layout of each biome is variable between each run, so gameplay is seldom repetitive

Reasons why I don't recommend:
- Difficulty (for those coming from Hades, expect a significant difficulty bump esp. in latter biomes)

Expect to try, and fail, a lot if this is your first rougelite/rougelike. Overall, highly recommend even at full price. Would still suggest finding the game discounted as sales on Steam are quite frequent in general.

The developer's focus seems to be on borrowing as much as it can from other games in its genre and never takes any of its ideas beyond their most basic form. There's a solid gameplay loop underpinning everything you do, but ultimately little things build up over time that make the game feel very derivative.

The writing has made me cringe on several occasions, the many references to other games get stale, none of the game's areas feel connected in any meaningful way, the weapons rarely feel unique (and even more rarely are they exciting to use), and I haven't once felt like the mutations made an impact on my run.

If I continued to play this, I'd probably have fun plenty of the time. But it's begun to feel hollow.

Когда-то я писал очень положительный обзор на эту игру, но тогда я еще не настолько сильно познал эту игру, поэтому сейчас я решился сказать немного другие слова и мысли. 

Геймплей у этой игры очень даже интересный, затягивающий и сложный (последнее постепенно начинает угосать всё сильнее и сильнее, пока не появился режим помощи, с помощью которого абсолютно легко становится проходить изначально хардовую игру), но постепенно начинает раздражать тот факт, что большинство оружий впринципе не особо играбельны на высоких сложностях (возможно это сделано, чтобы игроки могли сами выбирать, насколько сложно будет играться, но ведь достаточно просто всю игру ходить с маленьким кол-вом свитков или с оружием низкого уровня, нафига вообще нужно большую часть оружия делать сомнительным, мне никак это не понятно). Музыка по началу может казаться нормальной, но постепенно она не просто приедается, а раздражает. Возможно в игре самой она впринципе еще может работать, но желание слушать треки за пределами игры нет. Задники выглядят прекрасно, спорить с этим не буду. Имеется множество интересных локаций, каждый из которых обладают уникальным строением. Мне не особо, однако, нравятся модели все существ, которые являются 3Д модельками с пиксельными фильтрами, как по мне, это выбивается из 2Д стиля очень сильно. Достижения получать в этой игре болезненно, долго, но когда ты их выполнишь без особенного режима (за исключением достижений с оружиями, в обычном прохождении хрен их получишь), получишь невероятную эйфорию. В этой игре есть интересный лор, но разработчикам на него плевать, поэтому он не сильно расскрыт, хотя с другой стороны мне всё равно на сюжетную составляющую игр, без неё могу спокойно играть в игру, чтобы играть, а не чтобы кинчик посмотреть, но хотелось бы немного больше инфы про эту вселенную. Есть три вида свитков, определяющие твою игру: брутальность, тактика и живучесть; брутальность довольно сложна для среднестатистического игрока этой игры, но частенько через неё удобнее играть, чем с остальными видами свитков, особенно битва на маяке; тактика является очень хорошим выбором как для начинающих игроков, так и для проверенных игроков, являющаяся самым полезными типом геймплея; с живучестью есть некоторая проблемка - она нужна исключительно для тех, кто очень часто тычки в лицо получают или для тех, кому нечего уже делать, так как полезных предметов с таким типом геймплея очень мало, есть конечно причина, почему оружие очень медленное, но уж лучше быстрым кинжалом нанести столько же урона, сколько и нанес один удар шар бабой на живучести, с которой играть вообще не весело и заторможенно. А еще забыл про очень странный скачек сложности сказать: почему-то слишком резко возрастает сложность игры на 2 и 4 клетке босса, что вызывает раздражение. 5 клетка практически такая же, как и 4, только в ней присутствует система хвори, стимулирующая игрока убивать как можно больше, быстрее, эффективнее, не более. 

Bad seeds  имеет хорошие локации, нормальные предметы, фигового босса, к которому ну вообще не хочется возвращаться (можно списать это на пробу пера) 

Fatal falls имеет хорошего босса, уникальные локации, красивый новый пейзжа (особенно вторая локации этого длс выглядит великолепно) и набор очень даже хороших предметов для гг. 

Rise of the giant  имеет невероятно сложные и шикарные локации, кастомизации внешности, отличные предметы. Непонятно лишь то, какой смысл это длс делать бесплатным, можно было это сделать в виде крупного обновления. В любом случае из всех дополнений, это является всё ещё самым лучшим (иронично, что все длс, стоящие деньги, проигрывают бесплатному, но именно так всё и есть на самом деле) 

Queen and the see имеет разнообразные, но весьма дерьмовые оружия, с которыми играть вообще не хочется (они в патче хорошие тонфы сделали неудобными, за что???), также ну такого себе финального босса, но вот чем тащит это длс, так это новой локацией и предфинальным боссфайтом. Новая локация выглядит очень хаотично, необычно, интересно, в отличие от всех остальных локаций, поэтому проходить его одно сплошное удовольствие (возможно это только я такой eбнyтый); новой битвой является маяк, который очень даже крутой, весёлый, шикарный до тех пор, пока ты не пытаешься пройти   это без урона. В общем и целом, длс было бы лучше, если бы оружие хотя бы норм были, а не полнейшим мусором, а так я считаю, что это длс даже лучше fatal falls  (имхо) 

Return to Castlevania...А вот это длс по-настоящему разочаровало и разбило меня. Враги все абсолютно такие же, как в самой игре (можно это оправдать тем, что именно из кастлы пришли некоторые враги в мёртвых клетках, но даже так это не отменяет тот факт, что появились копии существующих врагов, которые никто не просил), лишь скелет отличается, и то даже ему зачем-то копию сделали, классно. Оружие...мэх, пойдёт. Костюмы красивые, эстетичные и интересные, более про них нечего сказать. Первая локация выглядит хорошо, но вот она сама по себе абсолютно скучная настолько, что можно её без особых напрягов пройти всегда. Вторая выглядит очень красиво, но опять же, ничего интересного, появилась лишь агрессивная тварь Горгона, способная за короткий срок избить тебя до смерти и это классно. Зачем-то они решили сделать замудренный способ попасть во вторую локацию под конец игры, добавив в неё лишь Дракулу, которому настолько насрать на твое присутствие, что слишком лениться мешать тебе жить, умеющий вызывать проблемы только лишь из-за редки переворотов экрана, приём этот глупый если честно. Первый босс слишком медленный, но с другой стороны, очень сильно отличается от других боссов, всё ещё вписываясь в мир игры. Второй босс очень похож на Гримма из Холлоу Найта (люди говорят, что Гримм похож на Дракулу, но как-то всё равно), битва с которым, как мне кажется, слишком не похожа на любого босса, так как этот кусок дерьма постоянно сваливает с арены, из-за чего битва с ним очень сильно растягивается. Есть еще и третий босс, который является второй фазой второго и...она даже неплохая: эпично поставлена, монстр сам по себе довольно внушительный и опасный, атаки разнообразные, саундтрек хороший, но страшнее всего кол-во его здоровья, его слишком много, нужно очень много его бить проклятым мечем последнего уровня с очень хорошей прокачки, чтобы его убить, тем самым придётся даже в самом лучшем случае невероятно долго убивать, битва из-за этого становится надоедливой. Второй и третий босс имеют кривую атаку летучих мышей, из-за которой большая часть забегов на Дракуле и заканчивалась, ещё хуже, когда пытаешься эту атаку пережить без урона, возникающая порой прямо перед твоим лицом, как в таком случае выживать, я не знаю. Музыка из кастлы хорошая, но мне лично кажется, что она не подходит к этой игре, так что про неё говорить толком не буду, это чисто вкусовщина. Режим Рихтера очень кривой, но мне никогда он не был интересен. Каким-то образом ценник этого отвратительного длс практически такой же, как и сама игра. Я из-за обещаний думал, что: ,,Ух, сколько будет интересных боссов, локаций, врагов", а когда я узнал бешеный ценник, я думал: ,, Ладно, длс стоит практически как сама игра, возможно там будет очень много интересного, почти даже целая игра ". В итоге мои надежды абсолютно не оправдались, для меня это стало разочарованием года, так как длс выходило очень долго, без понятии, что разработчики всё это делали. 

Эта игра неплохая и вполне играбельная, но в последнее время стремительно становится хуже из-за сомнительных решений обновлений, неоднократных обманов, ухудшений баланса.

Dead Cells is a great game. The gameplay is fun, the levels are interesting despite most biomes sharing 50% of enemies, the music is overall really good, the references are fun, and the visuals... goodness, the visuals. I have no idea how a game that looks this good runs this well on my crappy computer that has 4 gigs of ram and shipped with Windows 8. The only notable lag was during one attack of one of the DLC bosses. I thoroughly enjoyed most of this game.

So, why am I giving a negative review?

In a nutshell: This game has no respect for you. This game hates you. It despises you. And there are two reasons for this: Damage output, and time.

First, damage. Normal enemies do way too much damage. Look, getting beaned by an attack because you threw out my parry too early? that's a skill issue. Losing half your health because you threw out your parry too early? That's cruel. Loosing a run because you threw out a parry too early against a normal enemy (NOT a big enemy) and lost half your health or got combo'd to death in a second? That's bull. Losing a 2+ hour run to the previous scenario? That's a call too turn on assist mode and severely reduce the enemy and trap damage output. Which I did eventually, and enemies still did a lot of damage. 20% enemy and trap damage, and the game still didn't feel fair at times.
And before anyone dismisses me with the thought 'git gud scrub' or 'hah, don't let this idiot a real souls game like-' I say:
-The first time I beat this game, I did it with assist mode off. That without any cells, but still.
-I've beaten Bloodborne's true ending, both the true ending and evil ending of Sekiro, and the remake of Demon Souls. And this game has more bull than any of them.
At least with Fromsoft games- or for a Rougelike example, Splunkey -you only lose 5-10 minutes, or like 15-30 in the later example, when you  go from full health to dead in less than 5 seconds. At least when the same thing happens to you in Noita, another brutally difficult Rougelite that's really cool, the main path only takes like 20-40 minutes and if you go for any of the side content that takes dozens of hours, it's a case of "you know what you were getting into." But Dead Cell? The most basic ending can take over 2 hours unless you speedrun. 2 whole hours, down the drain, because a basic enemy got a cheep shot at you in the latter half of the game.
...It's worth noting that the obscene damage output mostly has to do with normal enemies. Strangely, bosses do far more reasonable damage than normal enemies. Why is it that the enemies that are designed to be fought 1v1, or at least in closed and predictable environments, do less damage than enemies that can potentially be fought 1-3 at a time, and even more than that on the highest two difficulties? Don't get me wrong, the bosses are still brutal, but it's weirdly reasonable compared to the rest of the game.

The second reason is time. Like I said, runs taken at a casual pace can take over 2 hours. That's already a long time for an action rougelike. But that's not the BS part. The BS part is that, to get the intended experience, beating the game once isn't enough. Now, anyone who goes into a Rougelike/Rougelite with the intention of beating it once and then never touching it again isn't playing Rougelikes correctly. But there's a point where it gets obsessive. Once you beat the game, you unlock a boss cell, and activating it does several things:
* It makes 1-cell doors available, giving you access to more loot and shops, most importantly health item shops, which sell a rare item that refills one of the charges of your health flask.
* It makes extra enemies spawn, including some that I'm pretty sure are excusive to the NG+ runs.
* It decreases the amount of health potion refills that you get.
I actually like part of how the higher diffaculities work, it's a lot more interesting than just "HAHA YOUR SURVIVABILITY IS SO LOW THAT THE GAME IS NEARLY IMPOSSIBLE NOW LOL, GOOD LUCK IDIOT." But considering the damage output issues I said before, less health refills a big deal. Especially once you unlock the second cell, and the third cell, and the fourth, and the fifth. But the worst part is, to get the true ending, which is part of the intended experience, you have to get all 5 boss cells, and go through the Rise of the Giant DLC content, which the developers actually brag about being "too hard for most people to consider fair". While I enjoyed Rise of The Giant, I can't say it's ok to lock the true ending behind content that the developers brag about not being fair, and the base game is already unfair. (also the Rise of the Giant DLC is free, and you can just ignore that content if you don't like it and don't care about the true ending, so I don't know why it's DLC) But that's a minimum of six loops, realistically much more, to get the true ending, and the final one is longer. I'm fine with crazy difficulty settings, but locking the true ending behind it is uncool. I'd consider 2 or 3 cells to be the hardest semi-reasonable difficulty. 4 cells has mechanics that are clearly not designed for casual play, and 5... 5 is just nuts. You wanna know a game that does the "forces you to play at a higher difficulty to get the true ending" right? Monolith: After The End. That game has two difficulty levels: Normal and Hard, hard mode doesn't decrease your effective health, and the content between starting hard and getting the true ending is actually shorter than starting normal and getting the not-true ending. That's much more reasonable than the nonsense you have to go through to get the true ending in this game. And while I won't spoil the contents of the ending, lore-wise the true ending you get for defeating the true final boss of dead cells isn't worth it.

I don't believe my opinions are popular ones, but soulslike fans tend to be so masochistic that it borders on toxic, and they aren't afraid to let you know. But personally, despite thoroughly enjoying the game, I can't recommend it. If enemy and trap damage output was severely reduced, I'd consider recommending the game, but I don't think the devs would ever consider that. Plus, that's only half the issue, and the other half a fundamental flaw that would require changing part of the game's identity.

For the approximately 0 people who care, I plan on writing reviews for all of the DLC as well. But here's the short version: "If you must buy Dead Cells, all the DLC is  worth it except 'The Bad Seed' DLC, so get all the DLC except that one if you can"


TL;DR: Dead Cells is the best game that I would not hesitate to say "Don't play it, ever."

Why should I do you that disservice?  So yeah, I really wanted to hate this game, but sadly, I don't.  It's actually just too damned good - it has tons of content, sees tons of updates, plays silky-smooth and every run is fun. One of my favourite roguelikes of all times.

Make it to the end without dying. There's a combination of permanent items you unlock over time. At first you'll see some in the form of extra healing flask charges and retained money on death, but the rest are mostly alternative weapons and abilities unlocked so they may appear in future runs. If you've played Rogue Legacy 1 or 2, Dead Cells does not take the approach of permanent stat upgrades for future runs.

I like the variety of approaches to combat you're able to utilize; allocating stat upgrades to Brutality, Tactics, and Survival and choosing matching weapons+powers over the course of your run is neat! The "Metroidvania" design involves discovering permanent abilities that allow you to reach new locations and alternate stages. I love the branching stage selection and how you can take more paths through the stages as you progress over time. The sense of risk and reward is strong. I take riskier bets and die in dumb ways....

I think Dead Cells has a fun, meta sense of humor. The tie-ins with other indie games are pleasant. The accessibility options are very welcome and I'm happy they are included. And definitely a lot of optional features to make the game harder too! Options always good!

One of the best rogue likes out there, Dead Cells is probably the sort of game I'd replay even though I've finished everything several times before.

Good things :
- Banger soundtrack, literally every single track is great and this is a feat that few games achieve, it even has a recognizable style compared to other games and even uses motifs here and there. Boss fight themes are also good though compared to newer ones, the older ones definitely feel less great 

- Unique visuals of 3D pixelated stuff next to 2D pixelated backgrounds, works perfectly well for the game and a lot of designs look great, both the world itself and regular enemies, bosses and other characters (though the weapons do look a bit lazy)

- Really good replayability : not only are there several boss options for each part of the game, but there's also different ROUTES you can pick which means entire parts of the run will be different

- Unique layouts : a lot of the levels are generated randomly, but unlike some rogue likes that have pretty forgettable generation, here a lot of levels have unique easy to differentiate layouts : Undying Shores is mostly built on the side and inside of some sort of cliff, Sewers are absolute mazes, Clocktower is split into several extremely tall towers, Fractured Shrines is a bunch of flying islands and so on...

- Gameplay has a LOT of variety. There's 3 main playstyles depending on the type of scrolls you pick along the way, basically being defense, close range offense and ranged (with traps as well). The variety then also comes from the huge number of weapons the game has. Swords, spears, giant swords, a sword that loves you for some reason, a sword that curses you, close range bows, long range bows, a motherfucking cannon, a rapier, another rapier but it tears through space and time or something, a B O N E, daggers, boots or sandals, whips, a torch, a scythe, a crowbar, a bat, a lantern and so on...

- It's extremely cool that this game promotes other indie games through crossovers, I wish more games did that

- It manages to have interesting lore told through minimal dialogue and environment

Bad things :

[UPDATED] Initially I complained about the difficulty that feels rather insane that you need to master in order to clear the last ending of the game, but they now added Assist Mode so that's fine. I've no complaints left about the game.
The new updates have made it too difficult.  Buy it if you are masochistic.

This is not a constructive review. I just don't like it. Progression isn't fun like a soulslike. I never got a the fun and rewarding part of this roguelite, so I'm just going to quit trying to like it. 

Oh cmon, you can't hang on a ledge, it pulls you up automatically and you're at the mercy of whatever was up there. 

I don't like the combat with enemies. It's robotic and dry.

The weapons given are hit or miss and the process of learning what is what you learn the devs put lots of useless items. 

I get far, I die, and I don't feel like I deserved half that death. 

I start over, and I stop caring. I love roguelites too, but when I die in dead cells, I don't thing I deserved it like Dark Souls.

Corridors are claustrophobic and dense, forcing you to deal with the samey enemies on difficult terrain, requiring you to sit and wait for them to turn around, or dodge bombs from a place you need to wait to get to. 

Falling doesn't have fall damage, but a stupid stun. In a platforming game? WHY?

I really don't get the hype and the positive reviews.

Dead Cells is an awesome game that I've been playing for hours on end! The graphics are amazing and the music is so cool - it really helps create this dark, creepy atmosphere that's perfect for the game. It's also very funny.

The gameplay is super fun and challenging, but also really rewarding. There are so many different enemies and weapons to try out, and the combat system is just so satisfying. I love how fast-paced and fluid it is - it really keeps you on your toes!

One of the things I dislike about Dead Cells is how the levels are procedurally generated, it's mostly the same. It definitely makes things stale.

I will say that this game is pretty difficult - it's definitely not a walk in the park. But honestly, that's part of what makes it so fun! Every time you die, you just want to try again and do better. And when you finally beat a level or a boss, it's the best feeling ever.

Overall, I would highly recommend Dead Cells to anyone who loves fast-paced action games with a lot of depth and replayability. It's definitely one of my all-time favorites!

Such a fun game that I could not stop playing. Addictive gameplay with so many weapons, skills, and abilities to try out and combine. The game has really cool and fluid animations with an awesome soundtrack. The levels are all really distinct from each other in design and theming. The difficulty is brutal and most bosses are really challenging, but the game allows you to tweak the difficulty if you're having too much trouble. Dead Cells is an amazing roguelite and a deep action game that is just a blast to play.

I have played this game since the Hello darkness Update, all the way back in July of 2017 and it has been a hell of a ride. My hours as of review are a little off as I often played offline on a laptop or nowadays, offline on my steamdeck during travel. If I had to roughly estimate, add an extra 400-600 hours as of my time of reviewing to the 316 is currently says I have.

This game is a lovely piece of passion from the developers, though many rocky updates and balancing over the years, but now has found a lovely place in my Library. For those unaware, this is a Hard game, Brutally hard and punishing at certain times but despite that, is one of the most fun experiences I've had playing a metroidvainia in years. It balances just the right amount of movement, timing and combat to accommodate several different play styles, and has had a steady flow of updates for every year I have played. However before I shower this in praise, I must remind you that no game is truly perfect. For those who read this, there are some warnings I would like to administer to you.

1: The true final boss of this game is locked behind the worst difficulty of this game, something even I have only BEAT once in all my hours playing (Granted it should be said that the boss wasn't even in the game for a couple hundred hours of my playtime, and I took an extended break last year and restarted with a fresh file as I came back.)

2: Those looking for a story, you may be disappointed. You get pieces of the story as you play from rooms the CAN spawn, but don't always, meaning bits of information you get is directly determined by the RNG of the games level generation. Even then, a lot of things have to be assumed as you learn them which can lead to either confusion later or when in the instances where the game finally bluntly tells you something to the degree which it smacks you over the head with it's statements, feeling jarred by the sudden exposition vs the earlier vagueness. Now, this isn't a bad thing for those who just want to play a kickass game, just a pet peeve of mine and a few of my friends.

3: The beautiful movement systems in the game are sometimes beautifully jank. With a certain rune which I will not name for the discovery of the player, sometimes the walls can seem sticky despite trying to move away from them, leading to unwanted hits and inconsistent climbs. Similarly, ledge grabbing tend to vacuum you into the ledge as well, which if you were trying to drop from the ledge as you are avoiding an enemy, pulls you right back into the enemy's face, and you can't cancel the animation with the dodge roll in instances like that. There are also instances where I WANT that vacuum yet I fall right past the ledge despite moving up against it and in it's direction.

4: That last point leads to animation canceling as a whole. Hoo boy, the best I can say here is that AC seems inconsistent across the game, there are times which you can AC an attack in any stage of the animation, other times where you seem almost completely locked in despite just beginning the attack and you want to stop before the attack comes out. Same for when you dodge-roll or want to use utilities, There seems to be inconsistencies between what can an can't cancel those animations. It can break the fluidity of combat when you think you know what can and can't be canceled, and then suddenly you learn you have to keep in mind this one weapon or utility in particular that doesn't follow the flow of every other. (Sometimes this is in your favor with certain weapons though, so it's not all bad, more just a frustration at times.)

Now, those are the issues I have with this game, Seems like a lot, but that's because I had to honestly thing and be specific with my own pet pevees and experiences with this game to fine 4 items to talk about, as most are ultimately unimportant to enjoy the game as a whole. 

When it comes to what I love about this game, it has hundreds of weapons and utilities to collect and choose from as you play to spice up each run, and difficulties to unlock as you complete the game for those looking for greater and greater challenges. It has several different biomes across each tier of the game and all sorts of pathways for a person to go down based on what route they enjoy. The visual aesthetic of each area is absolutely stunning at times, the music is wonderful to listen to and each area has all sorts of little secrets you can dive into to find items to aid you. The game also has had several crossovers with other indie games bringing in various outfits, weapons and skills allowing for some nostalgia to peak through for other great games (Not to mention some of those items from the crossovers are absurdly strong.) The movement, while sometimes jank as mentioned earlier, can also be whole worlds of fun when it cooperates with you and you can use the various biome layouts to zip around a kill the enemies with the greatest of ease or speedrun the game for a few interesting items. When a certain unnamed rune was first introduce, it opened up a whole new possibility of enjoyment to this game, and I almost wish they added another movement rune to the game.

Ultimately though, this game runs on a cycle for new players: Go through a stage, try and get a blueprint drop from the various enemies body's, feed a character cells gathered along the way to get the weapon in your weapon pool, move to the next stage or die trying as you learn how an enemy or your own weapons will attack, repeat until you reach the end of the game. As you beat the game (or die after getting permanent runes) you unlock more boimes and items found through that run, the run variety increases and comfort is found as you get better with the weapons. It's not easy to collect everything in the game quickly, but damn if it isn't fun along the way.

Dead Cells is an incredible game that has taken the gaming world by storm. With its fast-paced combat, stunning graphics, and endless replayability, it's no wonder that the game has received numerous awards and accolades.

One of the standout features of Dead Cells is its responsive and fluid combat system. Players must use a wide variety of weapons and abilities to take on hordes of enemies, each with their own unique strengths and weaknesses. The game's combat is fast-paced and satisfying, with a wide variety of combos and strategies to master.

Another impressive aspect of Dead Cells is its metroidvania-style gameplay. Players must explore a vast interconnected world, unlocking new areas and paths as they progress through the game. The game also features a wide variety of gear and lock items, allowing players to customize their playstyle and tackle challenges in their own way.

The game's graphics are also top-notch, with stunning pixel art and attention to detail that bring the game's world to life. The game's sound design is also impressive, with a fantastic soundtrack and sound effects that add to the overall experience.

Despite its challenging difficulty, the game is incredibly addictive and offers hours of fun. The game also features a Daily Run mode, complete with leaderboards, allowing players to compete with friends and other players for the top spot.

Overall, Dead Cells is a must-play game for anyone who loves fast-paced action and metroidvania-style gameplay. Its responsive combat, stunning graphics, and endless replayability make it one of the best games of its kind. It's no wonder that the game has received numerous awards and accolades, including the Steam Award for "Best Action Game" and the Golden Joystick Award for "Best Indie Game."

After having played this game way back when it launched when it had no achievements and no DLCs to finishing it now with all DLCs and Boss Cells, I can confidently say this is worth every single penny.

What stands out the most about this game is how each level is carefully designed around its difficulty to allow you to get acquainted with the build you get, finding the rhythm and balance of each weapon and skill you have. From the following levels, the difficulty ramps up sharply, which can be frustrating for those who are expecting an easy difficulty curve.

Curiously, this game being a Metroidvania, and me not necessarily being a huge fan of it (because of the mindless traversing back and forth that it entails), I found the level structure of this game to be really easy to get into. With enough teleporters and the levels being really clear in their layout, you almost always end up wanting to explore the rest of the level.

Once you git gud at the game, you can start taking some bigger challenges, such as using Boss Cells (basically, increasing the difficulty). At this point, the difficulty curve just goes out the window and it really pushes you to nearly perfect your combos and abilities to their max, which feels very rewarding. If you feel even more suicidal, you can push yourself even further through challenges, cursing yourself (you get an item, but you die in one hit) or picking some incredibly risky builds (like 300% damage, but enemies deal the same amount, pretty fun). 

Throughout all of these monumental difficult jumps, I found a few quirks. Not ... necessarily bad ones, but quirks, mainly with how many enemies are essentially rehashes of a variety of basic enemies you encounter in the first levels. There are exceptions as usual, but you can never shake off that feeling that you are dealing with the same enemy wearing a different skin. That, and some of the bosses are downright annoying to deal with. I won't spoil which ones, but FUCK, they just become an exercise in patience, rather than timing or strategy.

In any case, as I previously stated, this game is worth every penny you may have. If you like roguelite metroidvanias, you can't go wrong with this one, and if you like a challenge, you probably won't find a better one than this one.

-Added notes below on 4/22/23.

Having spent well over 500 additional hours with the game since my original review, I thought it worth revisiting to provide an update on my thoughts.

Dead Cells has proven to be one of the most rich and fulfilling gameplay experiences for me as I traversed its crisp difficulty progression. The expression "Get good" or any variation of it is sometimes thrown at people in response to certain questions in Dead Cells; and while from an outside perspective it could be looked at as just being a dick, I've found that in this case, the answer sometimes genuinely is just getting good.

I cannot recommend this game any higher, if you have any interest in action roguelikes at all, this is worth playing.

One of the first Rogue likes for me, and an awesome experience. Quite challenging and at first difficult to adapt to, coming from Dark Souls type games. Frequently dying was something I was used to, but having to start (almost) completely over each time was brutal in the beginning (and sometimes still is).

For me the most remarkable thing about the game is the amount of progression you make in your own skills, being able to feel that, but at the same time being challenged by the game like it still is your first run. As a small example: dying in Prisoners Quarters the first time after activating 1 bsc. Sitting there, baffled, asking how on earth I would be able to finnish this difficulty, only to complete a run on that difficulty a day later. In this I also realized the amount of fun these difficulties bring, and how well balanced they are (for me at least, and up till now). 

I usually feel my interest in these types of games drop quite fast after the first succesfull run. It also happened with this one, but only to realize that when I picked it up again and activated the higher difficulty I had really missed out on probably the most fun part of the game. 

Final note: after glancing at the graphics I would have never picked up the game, but since I heard a lot about it I decided to give it a try. But after playing it I am just massively impressed by the visuals. It actually feels like playing something in full resolution. It completely fits in this day and age, right next to the "next gen" ultra graphics. So please don't let that fool you!
