A good (albeit incredibly repetitive) game that gets bogged down by the devs' Discord inner circles that consist of speedrunners and people with 2000 hours in the game.

The first couple of runs are fun, then you obtain the first boss cell and realize it isn't fun anymore. Getting hit is stupidly punishing which promotes degenerate gameplay and over-emphasizes just [i]ONE[/i] playstyle: pick fast weapons that can kill enemies before they get a chance to do anything.

I would wager that 80% of the game's items and weapons are actively detrimental because they're too slow and you risk getting hit. And past the first or second boss cell, getting hit means you literally might as well restart, because getting hit takes away a lot of health and you get about 4 heals per run.

The Malaise changes that were done a few years ago have further destroyed any semblance of fun or balance at higher BC's. The devs take all their feedback from the same circle of players that are all speedrunners and perfectionists. Everyone else, stay far away from this game.

After seeing the initial announcement for Dead Cells: Return to Castlevania, I had to give this game a try because I am a huge castlevania fan. To my surprise, I immediately went down the rabbit hole with Dead cells, immensely enjoying the swift gameplay style and how polished the game was (diversity in settings, music options). I have to applaud the Dead cells: Return to Castlevania DLC for being a great callback to castlevania in a dead-cells Castlevania mixed style, bringing together elements from both games smoothly. I think this is a great way to advertise Castlevania in 2023, and show younger crowds/generations the series and get people interested. While I initially got hooked as a result of Super Smash Bros. Ultimate,  having another game do a collab now amidst the surge of video game releases this year, really helps to promote the series. Overall, one the best games I've played next to the Castlevania games themselves, all topped off with great music. Not only do I get to listen Dead Cells soundtracks in one game, but Castlevania ones too! (What about Heart of Fire though, and Sorrow's distortion? Can't have them all, but Castlevania music is Castlevania music and is very good non the less).

i have bought this game for both my switch and PC, and it's safe to say that this is the best 25$ i've ever spent. even without the DLC, there's so much to do and so many new weapons and areas to unlock. but the DLC is amazing as well, they're at a good price and add a lot to the game that i haven't even gotten to yet. it's frustrating in a way that is addicting, and i can easily spend multiple hours in one session without getting bored. the game starts out difficult but gets easier once you learn how the enemies work, which is why the pacing is so good in this game. you redo the same areas and bosses enough that you get better and further each time, while still having a good amount of difficulty with new enemies as you progress deeper. all in all, this game is amazing and definitely worth your money

The game has everything you could want in a side-scrolling action game: tight controls, pixelated graphics that will take you back to the days of Super Nintendo, and a difficulty curve that will make you scream, cry, and then come back for more. Its like Dark Souls and Super Mario had a love child, and that child was raised by Castlevania.

The best part about Dead Cells is that every time you die (and you will die a lot), you get to start over with a fresh perspective and a new set of abilities. Its like playing a different game each time, except youre still stuck in the same pixelated nightmare.

If youre looking for a game that will test your reflexes, challenge your skills, and make you laugh at how many times you can die in one sitting, then Dead Cells is the game for you. Just be warned: once you start, you won't be able to put it down. Its like the Hotel California - you can check out any time you like, but you can never leave
Yep

Been playing this game for almost 4 years at this point and I can safely say it's my favorite rouge-lite. Combat is super fun with a wide variety of weapons and some really cool DLC to boot. The game has had constant developer support for the entire time I've been playing it with a constant cycle of updates that's kept the game fresh and fun. Dead Cells is a great game for anyone looking for a very tough, but mostly fair, challenge. I will note that if you're looking to beating the highest difficulty in the game, be prepared for a LONG journey. Took me over 200 hours to beat it for the first time. For those wondering whether you should get the DLCs: prioritize Bad Seed and Return to Castlevania since they give early game content, then Fatal Falls since it's mid-game content, then Queen and the Sea if you're looking to freshen up the endgame.
great one. a classic imo

A roguelite hack and slash metroidvania with a very large variety of items to choose from. Inside a run you will collect gold for shops, and loot cells to upgrade your upgrades. Once you win a run, you will unlock the next difficulty, which increases cells looted and generally makes things harder. After a few difficulties in, it got boring a grindy to me, but it was still fun up until that point.

Probably the best action rogue like plat-former out there unless you hate the art style. It doesn't pull any punches though and you may end up only ever able to finish half of the game. Still, it's quite a ride. I might jump back into it and I will say that at a glance, it seems, that the best feature of the game is that you can "pick" any of the major content launches to play. For example with two boss cells I saw items dropping and had never seen them before so I just ignored them. I didn't want to stop and read the text. There are slow down issues for me with a GTX 960 but usually it's not the cause of death but duh to the number of objects on the screen. I remember it seemed to happen less and less with every major content release so they've worked at it in the past and probably will continue to work on it in the future. 

I played Rogue Legacy and almost finished it but it didn't have as smooth a layout for speed running as this does. That might mean there was actually more level lay out diversity in Rogue Legacy but my experience is that this has been the smoothest experience for moving through the levels as quickly or carefully as you want. I also really appreciate that they broadened the setting without bogging down the game play with cut-scenes or too much text. That might not appeal to everyone as I think it might be fair to say that you get the flavor of the setting and you do take on the evils that have befallen the realm but there's a definite tinge of despair that what has happened can't be undone and there won't be anyone left to rebuild if you do somehow manage to stop what happened from continuing to happen.

Kill, die, learn, repeat. Perfect description of the game.

Don't come here if you expect to find some deep lore and story. There are both quite interesting (in my opinion) lore and story, but they're overshadowed by the overabundance of collaborations, easter eggs and references. Don't get me wrong - many of items and abilities from these updates are great, but they do water down game's original story and atmosphere.

What you should come here for - is quick and fun roguelike with metroidvania elements. The game looks, sounds and feels gorgeous, has its own sense of humor (though I wish it tried to break 4th wall less) and plays great. It is quite challenging - and there's way more challenging stuff than you can initially imagine. I'm far from completing everything the game has to offer, and I'm not even sure I'll ever will.

P.S. Castlevania DLC is great and shows all of the best sides of the game.

I wouldn't have thought you could combine rogue-like with metroidvania given that the hallmarks of each genre seem diametrically opposed (rogue likes built around short, repetitive cycles of play that are unique from each other, metroidvanias typified by long, exploratory action platforming while building a character's skills). This team seems to have cracked it though, there's not a rogue-like out there I've synced with more than this one. The devs are true egalitarians too, everyone at the studio making the same amount of money, and they've supported the crap out of this game with free and low-cost DLC packed with extra content. There's probably not a better value in gaming for the time you'll sink into it.

The game's graphics are stunning, featuring a beautifully detailed pixel-art style that brings the game's dark and eerie atmosphere to life. The music and sound design are also top-notch, further immersing players in the game's haunting world.

The gameplay in Dead Cells is fast-paced and challenging, with players having to rely on their reflexes and skill to survive. The combat system is smooth and satisfying, with a variety of weapons and abilities at the player's disposal. The game also features a unique permadeath system, meaning that each run is unique and players must start over from the beginning if they die.

The game's level design is also excellent, with each area feeling distinct and filled with secrets and hidden paths to discover. The game features a variety of enemy types, each with their own unique strengths and weaknesses, making each encounter feel fresh and exciting.

One of the most impressive aspects of Dead Cells is its replayability. The game's permadeath system and randomly generated levels mean that each playthrough is different and players can continue to enjoy the game even after completing it multiple times. The game also features a variety of unlockable weapons and abilities, giving players even more reasons to keep playing.

Overall, Dead Cells is an excellent action-platformer that is sure to please fans of the genre. The game's stunning graphics, smooth combat system, challenging gameplay, and replayability make it a must-play for anyone looking for a fun and exciting game to sink their teeth into.
Loving the music and the nastalgia! would recommend

Very fun game with extremely snappy controls. Incredibly high difficulty* with a very high skill ceiling and a moderate learning curve. Lots and lots of choices to make and builds to create, with many modifiers, as well as tons of upgrades, to accentuate build types. Strong status effects also help to make the game less about 'highest damage always' and more about potentially more strategic answers to problematic situations and/or enemies. With many unlocks and diverse ways to play the game, in addition to procedurally generated maps, each run feels brand new and engaging. A 'Custom Mode' also exists for those who prefer to play the same levels for practice or preference. The one critique I can give is not necessarily the fault of the developers, but the community mods appear to be lacking somewhat.

* Fortunately, those of us who suck at the game have the 'Assist Mode' which makes it very possible with a lot of practice to reach the highest 'Difficulty Level' (5BSC) and complete the game to experience its 'True Ending'.

Dead Cells it's like a dungeon crawler like the old one Castlevania: Symphony of the Night but in its own style. Your stats, equipment etc. reset if you die, and it's got a difficulty leveler, the higher the difficulty goes the variation of monster change, the level bosses change and now with the castlevania DLC they added some of the key weapons of the series and some monster designs i personally really like. 
over all, it's a great game if you are looking for some fast games or something longer (I've got some runs that lasted more than 2 hours easily) 
I think there is not more to say really 
PS: It's got mod support ;)

I'm not huge on Roguelikes and Roguelites,  and by that I mean I hate them with a fiery passion. I hate starting over from scratch.

This game hits a sweet spot in between Roguelike, with a reset to your levels and equipment on death, and progressive gameplay, in which equipment you've unlocked remains in the drop pool and skills you've unlocked remain yours.

You're going to be dying all the time, but it doesn't feel like being sent back to square one.

Beyond that, it's grim, but not without humor, ran-gen without being repetitive, and difficult without being unfair.

Give it a shot.

After fully completing this game's story, I would say that it is very much worth it's price tag.

Dead Cells is a very difficult game, it is a very challenging game, and it is not for the feint of heart. You will get frustrated when you die far into a run; it happens to everyone, no matter how much patience you have. However, the reward of moving on to your next Boss Cell (difficulty) is beyond worth it. The satisfaction of beating the final boss for the first time is amazing. You just conquered Dead Cells! ...Or did you? Seeing the amount of active Boss Cells in the spawn area grow inspires you to just keep pushing onwards in order to reach higher difficulties.

The DLCs for Dead Cells offer immense amount of new content to expand your runs as well. I would say that they are very much worth their price tags as well (Return to Castlevania is pricey, but the perfect love letter to this game's inspiration is deserving of such a high price tag.)
-Bad Seed gives early-game content
-Fatal Falls gives mid-game content (and my personally favorite biomes and least favorite boss)
-Queen and The Sea gives end-game content with a new ending
-Return to Castlevania gives both early and late-game content; however, you can only access it once per run

If you're debating whether or not to get this game, you've read this far, so go ahead and buy the game :]
If you do get the game because of this review, my advice to you is to put all of your scrolls into one category, don't maximize your health, maximize your damage! And use shields too, you don't need that extra weapon!

Old Fashioned Meatloaf

Ingredients
 
    1 lb. 90% lean ground beef
    1 cup dried bread crumbs
    1/2 cup diced yellow onion
    1/2 cup milk
    1 large egg beaten
    2 tbsp. ketchup
    1 tbsp. Worcestershire sauce
    1 tsp. dried parsley leaves
    3/4 tsp. salt
    1/2 tsp. garlic powder
    1/4 tsp. ground black pepper
    For the Topping:
    1/4 cup ketchup
    2 tbsp. packed light brown sugar
    1 tbsp. red wine vinegar

Instructions

    Preheat oven to 350° Fahrenheit.
    In a large bowl, add the beef, bread crumbs, onion, milk, egg, 2 tablespoons ketchup, worcestershire sauce, parsley, salt, garlic powder, and pepper. Use your hands to mush and mix these ingredients together until well combined.*

    Add the meat mixture to a loaf pan. Pat the meat down into an even layer.
    In a small bowl, add ¼ cup ketchup, the brown sugar, and vinegar. Stir to combine. Pour the sauce on top of the meatloaf and spread it into an even layer.

    Bake uncovered for 55 minutes.
    Let the meatloaf rest for 8-10 minutes before serving (or it may fall apart).**

Notes
*Be sure to mix the meat really well.  This is a very moist meatloaf recipe so under mixing can cause the meatloaf to be too soft/mushy.

I just beat 5 BC (no custom mode), and I gotta say this is up there with Hollow Knight as two of the best single player games of all time. Gameplay can be fast-paced and hack and slash like, or you can be slow and methodical if need be. The difficulty progression system is executed to perfection. Instead of giving freedom to the player like Hades to pick and choose aspects of the game to increase the difficulty, the game gives you "Boss Cells" which limit the amount of healing, and increase the amount of damage you effectively take, but it also gives you better loot with each Boss Cell. Each Boss Cell makes the game exponentially harder especially if you beat the previous Boss Cell through luck instead of skill.

Speaking of luck, the game has a fair share of luck, you have a small chance to get overpowered "Legendary" weapons and skills that can almost guarantee the chances of completing a run. This makes the game feel fresh. Making high DPS builds is the core aspect of the game. Dishing out damage and overall being aggressive. 

The progression system relies on collecting blueprints and unlocking them using cells to kill enemies. It starts off extremely quick in the early stages of the game as there are 100s of blueprints to collect (if you have all the DLCs which you should buy). Later on you get less and less blueprints as you already have most of the items unlocked and only the really hard to get blueprints are left. 

The lore behind the game is nice, don't get the endings spoiled. 

Buy all the DLC
Prioritise them in this order
The Bad Seed (Early Game Content) > Fatal Falls (Mid Game Content) > The Queen & The Sea (Late Game Content) > Return to Castlevania (Separate Story-line)  

If you're finding the game extremely difficult, there is an assist mode and custom mode, and no one really frowns on you for using any of them unless you abuse them too much. Especially custom mode, the developers intended for players to use it. Personally, I didn't need any of them. The game is also very accessible in general. Although if you have epilepsy, I'd be careful playing it. 

Here in India, I got the game for an extremely cheap price. The Game + First 3 DLC cost me around 1000 Rs which is about $13. But I'd be willing to pay $30 or more for it. It has way more content than any AAA game I have ever played even rivalling that of God of War. 

Cons - 
1.) A lot of what makes the game fun (variety and replayablity) is hidden behind DLC; the base game will not give you countless hours of gameplay.

2.) The game does a good job of balancing considering how many weapons there are, but that being said not all weapons are created equal. Experiment for yourself and see what you like. 

TL;DR -  ADHD satisfying hack and slash, with a reversely exponential progression system and an exponential difficulty system. Countless hours of fun. Can get tilting. Countless weapons and many of them are unique. Tons of synergies, it's very fun to sit down with the boys and strategise and see which combos are the most effective. 

PLEASE PLEASE, GIVE THE GAME A CHANCE. PEOPLE WHO LEAVE REVIEWS BASED ON 10 HOURS OF GAMEPLAY HAVE YET TO EXPERIENCE 60% OF THE REMAINING GAME.

Dead Cells is an awesome game! It's a mix of Metroidvania and roguelike, with fast-paced action and challenging levels. You get to choose from tons of weapons and abilities and explore procedurally generated levels filled with enemies and traps. The permadeath system adds to the challenge, but as you progress, you unlock new stuff that makes future runs easier. The graphics and music are also amazing. If you like action platformers or roguelikes, you gotta play Dead Cells!

First off the soundtrack is fucking amazing with each level having unique vibe because of the tunes, I wouldn’t listen to it outside of the game because it’s perfectly crafted for the specific stages so listening to the OST without the gameplay would give me nothing, but hearing the bangers when reaching the areas was great and made me give this game more chances than it deserves.

Unfortunately, the game is great only on paper, the gameplay is really inconsistent and I don’t enjoy around 60% of the mechanics and hate all the bosses with exception of Time Keeper.

Examples of those inconsistent mechanics that make the game unenjoyable are boss attacks getting delayed by your attacks after they signalized them and then hitting you out of nowhere, the elite enemy affixes, the lovely boss attacks where you just have to wait and dodge until they are finished, unable to do anything else or the boss damage cap that makes most weapons subpar. (this really shows the bosses are garbage).

The gameplay feels really good when I can play fast and impulsively, but the game massively punishes this type of gameplay and just gets you killed on 5 Cell difficulty.

Personally, I really liked the game in its early stages (That’s also when I played the game the most, and the real reason I have 266 hours on record while I’m currently hating on it).
I’m not gonna waste any more of my time on this cause it’s clearly not for me anymore but you can prolly give it a shot.

This game has such an amazing progression system. I'll put it down for weeks and then pick it up to find new weapons and perks and feel like I'm kicking ass until I get my ass kicked and put it down again. It's always evolving which is amazing. Nice work.

I dunno. I want to like the game but I just can't. There's a few problems that just kind've ruin it for me. The biggest one being movement/attacking. In a game like this, the movement and attacks should feel precise and snappy. They don't. Everything feels sluggish and non-responsive. It's like I'm made of jello or something. The dodging feels sluggish, the attacks feel sluggish, the weird "delay" (I say delay, but it isn't an actual delay, it's just what it feels like) that plagues every action you perform. Basically every other rogue/metroidvania-esque game got this right. Fucks sake, even the hentai game Scarlet Maiden got the snappiness and precision of movement and attacks right. That's easily 90% of my problem with the game and it just makes it feel awful to play.

The other problem that I have is enemies ignoring walls. Like, I can't throw bombs and have than ignore the very existence of walls, why can the enemies do that? Not really a complaint, just think it's weird and it makes encounters with literally any bomber enemies feel odd. Like, it wouldn't even bother me if it went both ways. Yeah, they can blast me with ranged attacks through walls and floors, but so can I... but you can't, so it's weird.

The last issue I have is that you're facing a default direction depending on where you are on the screen. So if you're currently facing right, to attack something to the left, you have to HOLD left. If you let off, you start attacking to the right. Instead of, I dunno, just letting me change direction and attack in that direction without having to hold a movement key. It's super wack to play around because one pixel is the difference between your default direction changing from right to left. I can't find a way to turn it off so it's whatever I guess.

But yeah, the sluggishness of the movement and combat is a deal breaker for me and it honestly feels like the reason the game is "difficult". Didn't feel particularly difficult when I was playing, just felt like I was fighting with my own character to get it to do what I wanted, when I wanted.
